Chamoun has denied that she posed nude publicly on her Facebook page, saying that the behind the scenes images were not for publication.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.sportetstyle.fr/girls/galeries/a,780,jackie-chamoun-au-royaume-des-skieuses-topless.html |language= French |date= 12 February 2014 |author= Isabelle Vatan |publisher= L'Equipe Sport&Style |title= Jackie Chamoun au royaume des skieuses topless }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.courrierinternational.com/article/2014/02/12/jackie-oh |publisher= Le Monde Courrier International |title= Jackie, oh! |author= Ziyad Makhoul |date= 12 February 2014 |language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.sunnewsnetwork.ca/sunnews/sports/archives/2014/02/20140215-081323.html |title= Naked fans support topless Lebanese skier Jackie Chamoun |date= 15 February 2014 |author= QMI |publisher= Sun News |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140224135113/http://www.sunnewsnetwork.ca/sunnews/sports/archives/2014/02/20140215-081323.html |archivedate= 24 February 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://sports.yahoo.com/news/mariachi-topless-lebanese-muse-olympic-slalom-035955693--oly.html?pt=BureoF2GVB/ |title= Mariachi, topless Lebanese muse take to Olympic slalom |date= 20 February 2014 |author= Luke Phillips |work= AFP |publisher= Yahoo Sports }}</ref>
In [[South Korea]], a furore has erupted over the loss of [[Viktor Ahn]] (Ahn Hyun-Soo) to Team Russia. Several newspapers reported the scorn of the Korean public and newspaper editors on the actions of the [[Korea Skating Union]]. The minister of sport and president of South Korea have both promised action in rooting out corruption and feuding at the organization that may have led to his "defection", in a bid to clean it up in preparation for the [[2018 Winter Olympics]] in South Korea. The Korean public is generally supportive of Ahn.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/sport/other-sport/article/1429786/fury-over-viktor-ahns-russian-gold-aimed-korean-skating-union |author= Agence France-Presse |publisher= South China Morning Post |date= 17 February 2014 |title= Fury over Viktor Ahn's 'Russian' gold aimed at Korean Skating Union }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/viktor-ahn-russia-2014-2 |title= Why A Korean Speed Skating Star Changed His Name And Started Racing For Russia |author= Tony Manfred |date= 16 February 2014 |publisher= Business Insider }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/10/sports/olympics/ahn-rejected-us-to-skate-for-russia.html?_r=0 |title= Rejecting the U.S. to Skate for Russia |author= Sam Borden |date= 9 February 2014 |publisher= New York Times }}</ref>
Selection of [[Ashley Wagner]] over [[Mirai Nagasu]] by the United States Olympic Team for ladies' singles figure skating caused some controversy, as at the selection competition, Nagasu finished ahead of Wagner. Wagner was selected on the body of her work, instead of the strength of her selection performance.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sportsgrid.com/controversy-2/ashley-wagner-face-is-your-first-winter-olympics-meme/ |title= ‘Ashley Wagner Face’ Is Your First Winter Olympics Meme |author= Rick Chandler |date= 9 February 2014 |publisher= SportsGrid }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/olympics-fourth-place-medal/mirai-nagasu--olympic-snub-remains--devastating---but-hopeful-for-future-144149306.html |title= Mirai Nagasu: Olympic snub remains 'devastating,' but hopeful for future |author= Kevin Kaduk |date= 30 January 2014 |publisher= Yahoo Sports }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20775569,00.html |title= Ashley Wagner Speaks Out About Olympic Ice Skating Controversy |author= Johnny Dodd |publisher= People |date= 13 January 2014 }}</ref> The unclear selection process, and the fact that the second-place finisher [[Polina Edmunds]] had no international experience lead to some calls of racism, as the selection of Wagner over Nagasu was due to international results, while Edmunds' was not. This was the first time that the USFSA (United States Figure Skating Association) selected a skater who had competed in the selection trials and lost over another on who had also competed, previous times had done this only for skaters who had been injured and unable to compete at trials.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.usaukonline.com/latest-news/42293-controversy-as-figure-skater-who-fell-twice-at-olympic-qualifiers-and-came-fourth-is-chosen-for-games-ahead-of-woman-in-third.html |title= Controversy as figure skater who fell TWICE at Olympic qualifiers and came fourth is chosen for games ahead of woman in third |author= Mandy Oteng |date= 13 January 2014 |publisher= USA-UK Online |work= Daily Mail (London) }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/01/14/mirai-nagasu-ashley-wagner-and-the-myth-of-the-golden-girl/ |title= Mirai Nagasu, Ashley Wagner and the Myth of the Golden Girl |author= Tao Jones |date= 14 January 2014 |publisher= Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
The use of ''legioneri'' by the Russian Olympic Team has caused both joy and controversy inside Russia. The foreign origin naturalized Russian Olympians have sparked some questioning about the state of native Russian athletes. While in other quarters, the fact that Russia is now attracting Olympic level competitors instead of only losing them to other countries is a sign of progress. Many of the adopted sportspeople have been warmly embraced by Russians.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.mid-day.com/articles/russias-success-in-sochi-olympics-is-imported/15101068 |title= Russia's success in Sochi Olympics is imported |author= AFP |publisher= MidDay |date= 18 February 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/russia-s-foreign-legion/1000448.html |title= Russia's 'foreign legion' finally marches to medals |date= 17 February 2014 |author= AFP |publisher= Channel NewsAsia }}</ref>
Following the games in July, four Slovenian officials were suspended for four years from [[International Ski Federation|FIS]] after they helped to falsify times and rankings to allow alpine skier Vanessa Vanakorn (best known as the British violinist [[Vanessa-Mae]] and represented for Thailand as her father is a Thai) to achieve an average of 140 points of fewer at an FIS event to enable her to qualify for Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/11/violinist-sochi-olympics-vanessa-mae-slovenia-ski|title=Violinist's pre-Sochi Olympic results rigged, claims Slovenia ski body|first=Associated|last=Press|date=11 July 2014|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016|via=The Guardian}}</ref> At an [[International Ski Federation|FIS]] event in [[Krvavec]], where she achieved her required score, she finished 6th (and last)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/results.html?sector=AL&competitorid=168683&raceid=78548|title=National Junior Championships - Ladies' Giant Slalom 19.01.2014|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> in the national junior championships, despite being over 14 years older to the next eldest contestant.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/winter-olympics/25802907|title=Violinist Vanessa Mae set to compete at Winter Olympics|first=Ollie Williams BBC Olympic sports|last=reporter|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> She also finished 7th (but last),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/results.html?sector=AL&competitorid=168683&raceid=78549 |title=FIS Race - Ladies' Giant Slalom 19.01.2014 |publisher= |accessdate=30 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820202640/http://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/results.html?sector=AL&competitorid=168683&raceid=78549 |archivedate=20 August 2016 |df= }}</ref> 9th (of 13th)<ref name="data.fis-ski.com">{{cite web|url=http://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/results.html?sector=AL&competitorid=168683&raceid=78547|title=FIS Race - Ladies' Giant Slalom 17.01.2014|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> and 10th (of 13th).<ref name="data.fis-ski.com"/> She finished with a total time of 3:26.97, 50.10 seconds behind the winner, [[Tina Maze]] of [[Slovenia]]. She was last among the finishers, ranking 67th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://olympics.cbc.ca/alpine-skiing/event/women-giant-slalom/index.html?v=20140218-105507680 |title=Alpine Skiing – Women's Giant Slalom |publisher=CBC Olympics |accessdate=18 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140218213350/http://olympics.cbc.ca/alpine-skiing/event/women-giant-slalom/index.html?v=20140218-105507680 |archivedate=February 18, 2014 }}</ref> During investigations by FIS, it was revealed that the event was [[match fixing|fixed]] to enable her to compete, for example a result including a competitor who was not present in the races, was placed 2nd in one race despite falling and her time was adjusted afterwards by more than 10 seconds, enabling a previously retired competitor who had the best FIS points in the competition to lower the penalty to benefit participants, failing to alter the course between runs and allowing the race to be run despite being suitable under regulations.<ref name="dothaneagle"/> As a result of taking part in a race rigged to her favor in an event orchestrated by her [[talent manager|manager]],<ref name="dothaneagle">{{cite web |url=http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/entertainment/vanessa-mae-banned-over-fixed-olympic-qualifiers/article_ea2dae50-a8ef-5ac8-8de4-21f1962767b7.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141111231949/http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/entertainment/vanessa-mae-banned-over-fixed-olympic-qualifiers/article_ea2dae50-a8ef-5ac8-8de4-21f1962767b7.html |archivedate=2014-11-11 |df= }}</ref> Vanakorn was banned from skiing for four years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/winter-sports/30005830|title=Vanessa-Mae: Skiing violinist banned for four years|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref>
==Pegasus Airlines Flight 751== <!-- Anchor from redirect; caution. --> On 7 February 2014, during the [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] and one day after the start of the [[2014 Winter Olympics]], a man attempted to hijack [[Pegasus Airlines]] Flight 751<ref>Note: IATA code: PC 751, ICAO code: PGT 751, Callsign: ''SUNTURK 751''</ref> that was on a flight from [[Kharkiv]], [[Ukraine]], to [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], saying he had a bomb on board, and demanding to be flown to [[Sochi]], the host city of the 2014 Winter Olympics.<ref name="AviationSafety Pegasus">{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20140207-0 |title=ASN Aircraft accident Boeing 737-86J (WL) TC-CCP Istanbul-Sabiha Gökçen International Airport (SAW) |publisher=Aviation-safety.net |date= |accessdate=2014-03-12}}</ref><ref name="CNN Pegasus">{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/07/world/europe/turkey-flight-bomb-threat/index.html|title= Official: Plane lands in Turkey after bomb threat, passenger wants to land in Sochi |date= 7 February 2014 |author1= Gul Tuysuz |author2= Michael Martinez |work=CNN}}</ref><ref name="FoxNews Pegasus">{{cite news|title=Passenger on Istanbul-bound flight makes bomb threat, tries to hijack plane to Sochi|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/02/07/turkish-authorities-search-plane-over-bomb-claim/|work=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=8 February 2014|date=7 February 2014}}</ref> The pilots turned off the inflight monitors and landed at Istanbul's [[Sabiha Gökçen Airport]], fooling the man into thinking he was landing in Sochi. The plane, a [[Boeing 737-800]] reg TC-CCP, was escorted to Istanbul by two [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[F-16]] fighter jets. The man, who appeared to be severely intoxicated, was detained by police and taken to the [[Istanbul Security Headquarters]].<ref name="CNN Pegasus"/><ref name="NYTimes Pegasus">[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/08/world/europe/attempted-hijacking-of-turkey-bound-plane-reported.html ''Attempted Hijacking of Turkey-bound Plane Reported'']; [[NY Times]] online; retrieved February 2014.</ref><ref name="Telegraph Pegasus">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10625034/Winter-Olympics-Bomb-threat-forces-plane-from-Ukraine-to-land-in-Turkey-after-hijack-attempt.html ''Winter Olympics Bomb Threat Forces Plane from Ukraine to Land in Turkey After Hijack Attempt]; [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]; retrieved February 2014.</ref><ref name="mirror">{{cite web | last=Evans| first=Natalie| title=Ukrainian plane makes emergency landing in Turkey after 'hijacker attempts to divert to Sochi' https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/sochi-2014-attempted-hijack-forces-3122725#ixzz2sfRYEPQP| url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/sochi-2014-attempted-hijack-forces-3122725| publisher=The Mirror| accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> In 2018, Russia's President [[Vladimir Putin]] admitted that he ordered the shooting down of a passenger plane that was reportedly carrying a bomb and targeting the opening of the 2014 Winter Olympics.<ref name="BBC News">[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43365800 "Putin ordered plane to be downed in 2014"]; retrieved 12 March 2018.</ref><ref name="Euronews">[http://www.euronews.com/2018/03/11/putin-order-for-bomb-threat-plane-to-be-downed-in-2014-cancelled-after-false-alarm "Putin order for bomb threat plane to be downed in 2014 cancelled after false alarm"]; retrieved 12 March 2018.</ref>
==Environment== {{See also|Environmental issues in Russia}} [[File:XXII olympic winter games in Sochi.jpg|thumb|XXII Olympic winter games in Sochi. The souvenir sheet of Russia, 2011]] Despite several expert statements<ref>[http://www.ikd.ru/node/1876 Note of environmentalists against 2014 Olympics in Sochi]. ikd.ru, 29 December 2006 {{ru icon}}</ref><ref name="world_heritage">[http://sport.gazeta.ru/sport/2007/07/a_1881085.shtml World heritage is in danger]. Gazeta.ru, 5 July 2007 {{ru icon}}</ref> that the construction of Olympic venues in the buffer area of the [[UNESCO]] protected [[Caucasus]] Biosphere Reserve and [[Sochi National Park]] could be harmful, the [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] approved the plans. [[Greenpeace]] of Russia said that the IOC and the [[Government of Russia|Russian Government]] assumed all responsibility for any damage to the [[West Caucasus]] natural [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. According to the [[Sochi bid for the 2014 Winter Olympics|Sochi bid]], a wide array of construction was planned in the [[Grushevyi Ridge]] area. They included a cascade of [[hydroelectric]] [[power station]]s on the [[Mzymta River]], [[sewage treatment]] facilities, a high-speed rail link, a Mountain Olympic Village, a track for bobsleigh, luge and skeleton (which was relocated in May 2009), and a biathlon venue. Alpine skiing venues were being constructed in the [[Rosa Khutor Alpine Resort|Rosa Khutor]] plateau and the [[Psekhako Ridge]] area. Environmentalists proposed building up [[Krasnaya Polyana, Sochi, Krasnodar Krai|Krasnaya Polyana]] instead of destroying [[nature reserve]] sites.
Environmentalists also opposed the plan of construction of a [[container terminal|cargo terminal]] for ships in the mouth of the [[Psou River]] in the [[Imereti Lowland]], because this could lead to the destruction of the largest areas of sea-flooded shore and marshes.<ref>[http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/newstext/news/id/1192223.html Environmentalists: Kuban authorities prepare to sacrifice one more nature site for the Olympics]. Kavkazsky Uzel, 18 June 2007 {{ru icon}}</ref>
On 3 July 2008, [[Vladimir Putin]] directed some of the Olympic venues, such as the luge and bobsleigh track, to be relocated (the [[Russian National Sliding Centre]] was relocated in May 2009). He said "In setting our priorities and choosing between money and the environment, we're choosing the environment."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/03/AR2008070301912.html|work=The Washington Post|first=Peter|last=Finn|title=Putin Directs Organizers of 2014 Winter Olympics to Protect Wilderness|date=3 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/600/42/368730.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080804183735/http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/600/42/368730.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=4 August 2008|title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090115165241/http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=12836886&PageNum=0 Putin blasts Olympics organizers for imperfect building projects] – [[ITAR-TASS]]</ref>
Geologist Sergei Volkov fled to Ukraine after speaking out about environmental and geological problems. He stated that [[mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[uranium]] deposits, as well as the probability of [[landslides]], made the location of the games hazardous. He also argued that the location of a [[container terminal|cargo port]] was inappropriate. A storm there killed three [[seaman|seamen]] and destroyed $14 million of infrastructure.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8624894.stm|work=BBC News|title=Russia scientist flees after Olympic alerts|date=16 April 2010|first=Richard|last=Galpin}}</ref>
On 29 October 2013 it was reported that Russia broke its 'Zero Waste' Olympic Pledge, as it emerged that Russia's state-owned rail monopoly was dumping tons of construction waste into an illegal landfill, raising concerns of possible contamination in the water that directly supplies Sochi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.com/Sports/wireStory/russia-breaks-waste-olympic-pledge-20717263?singlePage=true|title=Associated Press, Russia Breaks 'Zero Waste' Olympic Pledge, 29 October 2013 |publisher=Abcnews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-07}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
==Animal rights== The issue of stray dogs has come up before the Olympics. On 3 February 2014, the city hired a firm to exterminate the stray population – an approach that has brought international condemnation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/sochi-company-hired-to-kill-stray-dogs-ahead-of-olympic-games-1.2521671 |title=Sochi company hired to kill stray dogs ahead of Olympic Games – World – CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2014-02-03 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sochi officials order stray dogs killed ahead of Olympics|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/02/03/sochi-officials-order-stray-dogs-killed-ahead-olympics/|work=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=8 February 2014|date=3 February 2014}}</ref> These plans have been abandoned after complaints by local citizens. The stray dogs will be collected from the streets and put in a shelter.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2013/04/18/sochi-russia-winter-olympics-cats-dogs-/2093817/|title=Sochi officials back off plan to kill stray animals |publisher=USA TODAY |date=2013-04-18 |accessdate=2014-02-07 |first1=Kelly |last1=Whiteside}}</ref>
Russia originally planned to have two orca whales perform in the opening ceremonies of the Sochi 2014 Olympics. They were two of eight whales captured off the coast of Russia.<ref name="Where in the World is Narnia, the Sochi Olympics Orca?">{{cite web|url=http://www.earthisland.org/journal/index.php/elist/eListRead/where_in_the_world_is_narnia_the_sochi_olympics_orca|title=Where in the World is Narnia, the Sochi Olympics Orca?|publisher=Earth Island.org|date=February 4, 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> After backlash by various advocacy groups and petitions signed by the general public, a statement was released that the whales would not be part of the Olympics.<ref name="Sochi Olympics Set to Feature Killer Whales">{{cite web|url=http://news.discovery.com/animals/whales-dolphins/sochi-olympics-set-to-feature-killer-whales-140123.htm|title=Sochi Olympics Set to Feature Killer Whales|publisher=Discovery.com|date=6 February 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> The current whereabouts of the whales are unknown.
It was rumored that the committee had planned to have a dolphin trained to carry the Olympic torch. Activists spoke up about the issue immediately, causing the President of the Olympics Committee, Dmitry Chernyshenko, to issue the statement that, "I confirm that we do not involve any orcas or dolphins for the Olympics."<ref name="Protests Trigger a Rethink in Sochi">{{cite web|url=http://www.oceancare.org/en/news/?75/ProteststriggerarethinkinSochi|title=Protests Trigger a Rethink in Sochi|publisher=Ocean Care.org|date=6 February 2014|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> Whether or not there had been any plans for a dolphin torchbearer has never been confirmed.
==Economy== According to ''[[The New York Times]]'' the $50 billion or so lavished on Sochi is becoming a political liability. The stalling of the economy, despite the stimulus of Olympic spending, has raised worries about popular unrest directed at the Kremlin and a tightening of political freedoms in response once the Games are over. "It is about what Russia could have done with this money." said Aleksei A. Navalny, the Foundation for the Fight Against Corruption.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/07/world/europe/russias-economic-malaise-casts-specter-over-games.html A Triumph for Putin, if Not for the Rest of a Sagging Russia] New York Times, 5 December 2013</ref>
According to IRN.Ru analytical agency, prices for land, located next to the shoreline, reach $150,000 per 100 m²,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100122105854/http://www.strana.ru/doc.html?id=69493 Struggle with «olympic» swindlers in Sochi]. Strana.Ru, 19 July 2007 {{ru icon}}</ref> while price per square metre in average panel [[apartment building]] on the outskirts of the city already reaches $2000. "As a result of 2014 Olympics euphoria prices will rise annually by 15–20%," speculates Irina Tyurina, press secretary of Russian Tourist Industry Union. This could lead to decrease in tourist interest to Sochi, which already has fallen below [[Anapa]], [[Gelendzhik]] and Adler.<ref name="not_a_place">[http://sport.gazeta.ru/sport/2007/07/a_1880984.shtml Sochi is not a place for recreation]. Gazeta.ru, 5 July 2007 {{ru icon}}</ref>
After the IOC Evaluation Commission visited Sochi in February 2007, local authorities promised to buy the lands from [[Lower Imereti Bay]] long-time residents for a fair market price. But during the following half a year, no local resident could get their land approved as private property.<ref name="world_heritage"/>
While most Olympic Games have high cost overruns, for these Games they are much higher than usual. Much of the cost overruns have been blamed on corruption, with [[Boris Nemtsov]] claiming: "The Sochi Olympics are an unprecedented thieves' caper in which representatives of Putin's government are mixed up along with the oligarchs close to the government." <ref name="economist-sand">{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21581764-most-expensive-olympic-games-history-offer-rich-pickings-select-few-castles|title=The Sochi Olympics: Castles in the sand|publisher=The Economist|date=July 13, 2013|accessdate=January 5, 2014}}</ref> According to research by [[Transparency International]], a global anti-corruption watchdog, approximately 50 percent or more of the building costs went to corruption.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/olympics--one-year-out--sochi-s-winter-olympic-celebration-is-already-dogged-by-allegations-of-massive-corruption-162804429.html|title=One year out, Sochi's Winter Olympics is already dogged by allegations of massive corruption|publisher=Yahoo Sports|date=Feb 7, 2013|accessdate=February 24, 2014}}</ref>
Poor workers conditions and rights have also been raised as an issue of concern, with at least 25 people dying and many more injured in accidents on sites in 2012 and with workers not getting paid at all.<ref name="economist-sand" />
==Circassians== {{main|Ethnic cleansing of Circassians}} [[File:Çerkez sürgününün anılması 1.jpg|thumb|Turkish Circassians commemorate the banishment of the Circassians from Russia in [[Taksim Square|Taksim]], [[İstanbul]]]] [[Circassians|Circassian]] organisations have also spoken out against the Olympics, arguing that the Games will take place on land that had been inhabited by them since the beginning of recorded history by their ancestors until 1864,<ref>Jaimoukha, Amjad. ''Ancient Circassian Cultures and Nations in the First Millennium BCE''. Pages 1–7, 9–14</ref><ref>Encyclopædia Britannica entry for Circassians: "From ancient times Circassia, comprising roughly the northwestern region of the Caucasus, acquired the exotic reputation common to lands occupying a crucial area between rival empires..."</ref> when the resolution of the [[Russian–Circassian War]] was stated to have caused the disappearance (variously by death or deportation) of 1.5 million Circassians, or 90<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS104971+22-May-2009+PRN20090522|title=145th Anniversary of the Circassian Genocide and the Sochi Olympics Issue|date=22 May 2009|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=28 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702174523/https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/05/22/idUS104971%2B22-May-2009%2BPRN20090522|archivedate=2 July 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/21/world/europe/21georgia.html|title=Georgia Says Russia Committed Genocide in 19th Century|author=Ellen Barry|date=20 May 2011|work=The New York Times}}</ref>-94%<ref>Sarah A.S. Isla Rosser-Owen, MA Near and Middle Eastern Studies (thesis). ''The First 'Circassian Exodus' to the Ottoman Empire (1858–1867), and the Ottoman Response, Based on the Accounts of Contemporary British Observers.'' Page 16: "... with one estimate showing that the indigenous population of the entire north-western Caucasus was reduced by a massive 94 per cent". Text of citation: "The estimates of Russian historian Narochnitskii, in Richmond, ch. 4, p. 5. Stephen Shenfield notes a similar rate of reduction with less than 10 per cent of the Circassians (including the Abkhazians) remaining. (Stephen Shenfield, "The Circassians: A Forgotten Genocide?", in The Massacre in History, p. 154.)"</ref> of the Circassian nation. They are demanding the Sochi 2014 Olympics be cancelled or moved unless Russia apologises for what the Circassians regard to be a [[Circassian Genocide|genocide]].<ref name="reuters.com"/> Some Circassian groups have not expressed outright opposition to the Olympics but argue that symbols of Circassian history and culture should be included in the format, as Australia, the United States, and Canada did with their indigenous populations in [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000]], [[2002 Winter Olympics|2002]], and [[2010 Winter Olympics|2010]] respectively.<ref>Azamat Bram. [http://iwpr.net/?p=crs&s=f&o=339641&apc_state=henpcrs Circassians Voice Olympian Anger]. [[Institute for War and Peace Reporting]] Caucasus Reporting Service No. 413, 5 October 2007. Retrieved on 2 April 2010.</ref>
The games are viewed to be particularly offensive because they include the date of the 150th anniversary of what they consider a genocide. It has thus been a rallying cry for [[Circassian nationalism|Circassian nationalists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.circassianworld.com/new/general/1382-circassian-dimension-2014sochi-szhemukh.html|title=The Circassian Dimension of the 2014 Sochi Olympics|last=Zhemukhov|first=Sufian|date=September 2009|work=PONARS Policy Memo No. 65 – Georgetown University|publisher=Circassian World|accessdate=28 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091011120907/http://www.circassianworld.com/new/general/1382-circassian-dimension-2014sochi-szhemukh.html|archivedate=11 October 2009|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS104971+22-May-2009+PRN20090522|title=145th Anniversary of the Circassian Genocide and the Sochi Olympics Issue|date=22 May 2009|agency=Reuters|accessdate=28 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702174523/https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/05/22/idUS104971%2B22-May-2009%2BPRN20090522|archivedate=2 July 2012|df=}}</ref>
In particular, there is much ire over the use of a hill called "Red Hill".<ref name="NorthJersey-redhill">{{cite news|date=9 February 2010|author=Andrea Alexander|title=North Jersey Circassians 'in exile' launch Olympic protest|work="NorthJersey.com"}}"In 1864 a group of Circassians tried to return home but were defeated in a bloody battle on a mountain that became known as "Red Hill."
"That is where the ski lifts and ski events will be held, at the Red Hill," said Zack Barsik, president of the local Circassian Institute. "The Olympic events of skiing and snowboarding will be held on that same mountain."</ref> In 1864, a group of Circassians apparently tried to return home but were attacked and a battle ensued, ending in their massacre, and attaining the name "Red Hill" (for the blood spilled). There were skiing and snowboarding events planned to be held on this hill.<ref name="NorthJersey-redhill"/>
==Political stability and governance== The 2008 [[Russia–Georgia war]], which broke out at the start of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], surprised the Olympic community. "It is not what the world wants to see. It is contrary to what the Olympic ideal stands for", said an IOC spokesperson. However, in November 2008, the IOC turned down a request by the [[Georgian National Olympic Committee]] to reconsider its decision to hold the Olympics on the territory "adjacent both to the [Russian-]occupied Abkhaz conflict zone, and to the extremely unstable and volatile North Caucasus".
Related concerns persist, regarding the region's safety and the desirability of hosting an Olympics in a conflict-ridden zone. "The region is such a muddied and bloodied aquarium of conflict that to pick out any one fish is impossible," says [[Oleg Nechiporenko]], chief analyst for Russia's National Anti-Terrorist and Anti-Criminal Fund, in response to a 26 May 2010, car bombing, whose suspects include Russian nationalists, local [[Russian mafia]] groups, [[Separatism|separatists]] and [[Islamists]] in the North Caucasus, or a remnant of the war in [[Abkhazia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1992911,00.html|work=Time|first=Simon|last=Shuster|title=Is Sochi Safe Enough for the Olympics?|date=30 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/sochi-2014-the-terrorist-threat-8890?page=show|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819203315/http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/sochi-2014-the-terrorist-threat-8890?page=show|archivedate=2013-08-19 |title=Commentary: Sochi 2014: The Terrorist Threat |publisher=The National Interest |date=2013-08-15 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref>
Sochi borders Russia's six autonomous North Caucasus republics, home of the [[Second Chechen War]] which allegedly face social problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,680560,00.html|title=Opinion: Will Olympic Flame Dim in Sochi?|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=23 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110401212818/http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0%2C1518%2C680560%2C00.html|archivedate=1 April 2011|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> According to an article in Daily Telegraph, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, head of [[Saudi]] intelligence, allegedly confronted the Kremlin with a mix of inducements and threats in a bid to break the deadlock over Syria. This included security of winter olympics in Sochi if there is no accord. "I can give you a guarantee to protect the Winter Olympics next year. The Chechen groups that threaten the security of the games are controlled by us," he allegedly said.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/oilandgas/10266957/Saudis-offer-Russia-secret-oil-deal-if-it-drops-Syria.html |title=Saudis offer Russia secret oil deal if it drops Syria |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |date=2013-08-27 |location=London |first=Ambrose |last=Evans-Pritchard}}</ref>
Russian Envoy to the North Caucasus [[Alexander Khloponin]] told local law enforcement that "the violent scramble for assets" is likely to get worse as Russia invests heavily in tourist infrastructure and Olympic-caliber ski resorts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1992911,00.html|title=Is Sochi Safe Enough for the Olympics?|date=30 May 2010|work=Time|first=Simon|last=Shuster}}</ref>
===Safety=== Three suicide bombings in [[Volgograd]], one [[October 2013 Volgograd bus bombing|in October 2013]] and the others [[December 2013 Volgograd bombings|in December 2013]], have raised additional international concerns about security during the Olympics. The IOC expressed sympathy for the victims and underlined that they trusted that Russia's security arrangements for the Olympics would be adequate.<ref name=npr>{{cite news|date=30 December 2013 |url=http://npr.org/story.php?storyId=258035156 |title=Russia Bombings Kill 31, Raise Concern On Olympics |agency=Associated Press |publisher=NPR |accessdate=1 January 2014 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The British, German, Italian, Hungarian, Austrian, Slovenian and Slovakian Olympic associations received threats that athletes would be "blown up" or kidnapped by terrorists at the Winter Games.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/winter-olympics/10590826/Winter-Olympics-2014-email-threat-to-blow-up-athletes-at-Sochi-Games-dismissed-by-IOC.html|title=Winter Olympics 2014: email threat to 'blow up' athletes at Sochi Games dismissed by IOC|work=Telegraph|date=22 January 2014|accessdate=30 January 2014|location=London|first=Ben|last=Rumsby}}</ref> According to the IOC, the letters did not represent any real threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.ria.ru/sochi2014/20140122/186809712.html |title=European Olympic Committees Report Sochi Terror Threats |publisher=En.ria.ru |date=2014-01-22 |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref>
{{Main|Concerns and controversies at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Pegasus Airlines Flight 751}} On 7 February 2014, during the [[2014 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]], a [[Pegasus Airlines]] flight from [[Kharkiv]], [[Ukraine]], to [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]], was threatened by a passenger who attempted to hijack the jetliner with a demand to be flown to [[Sochi]].<ref name="CNN Pegasus"/><ref name="FoxNews Pegasus"/> The man would be detained by police and taken into custody.<ref name="AviationSafety Pegasus"/><ref name="NYTimes Pegasus"/><ref name="Telegraph Pegasus"/>
== Media coverage == IOC President [[Thomas Bach]] criticized attempts to politicize the Games, saying that governments should not send political messages "on the backs of their athletes."<ref name="Macur2014">{{cite news |last=Macur |first=Juliet |date=23 February 2014 |title=Amid the Triumphs, an Argument for Tolerance: Olympic Closing Ceremony Proves Russia a Worthy Host |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/24/sports/olympics/olympic-closing-ceremony-proves-russia-a-worthy-host.html |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> Benjamin Bidder of ''[[Spiegel Online]]'' and [[Julia Ioffe]] of ''[[The New Republic]]'' compared the negative pre-Sochi coverage to [[schadenfreude]] and [[Russophobia]], while Anton Fedyashin of ''[[The Guardian]]'' blamed lingering Cold War mentalities for "dishing up a feast of negativity."<ref name="Fedyashin2014">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/24/sochi-olympics-west-not-over-cold-war |title=The real political takeaway from the Olympics: the west needs to get over the cold war |last1=Fedyashin |first1=Anton |date=24 February 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> In an editorial published by ''[[The Nation]]'', scholar of Russian studies [[Stephen F. Cohen]] criticized the "toxic coverage" for "exploiting the threat of terrorism so licentiously it seemed pornographic."<ref name="Cohen2014">{{cite news |last=Cohen |first=Stephen F. |date=11 February 2014 |title=Distorting Russia: How the American media misrepresent Putin, Sochi and Ukraine |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/178344/distorting-russia |newspaper=The Nation |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> He further wrote that "American media on Russia today are less objective, less balanced, more conformist and scarcely less ideological than when they covered Soviet Russia during the Cold War."<ref name="Cohen2014"/>
According to ''The Guardian'' the games were more politicised than the before, serving as shameless promotion of Putin's Russia.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/dec/30/volgograd-bombs-ignoring-olypmic-politics-excesses-sporting-protest-terrorism The Volgograd bombs are a warning over Olympic excess], theguardian, 30 December 2013</ref> While former world chess champion and Russian opposition figure [[Garry Kasparov]] said that game bolstered Putin's [[cult of personality]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/07/sochi-vladimir-putin-hitler-berlin-garry-kasparov Sochi is to Putin what Berlin in 1936 was to Hitler, says Garry Kasparov], The Guardian, 7 February 2014</ref>
Comedians and satirical newspapers took advantage of the widespread pessimism. On 8 February, ''[[The Daily Currant]]'' posted a story alleging that a man responsible for operating the Olympic rings during the opening ceremony, which famously suffered a technical glitch, had been "found dead...with multiple stab wounds."<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=8 February 2014 |title=Man Responsible For Olympic Ring Mishap Found Dead In Sochi |url=http://dailycurrant.com/2014/02/08/man-responsible-for-olympic-ring-mishap-found-dead-in-sochi/ |newspaper=The Daily Currant |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> The fictional story went viral on social media.<ref name="Aguila2014">{{cite news |last=Aguila |first=Lou Ramon |date=10 February 2014 |title=2014 Sochi Olympics: Terrorist Plot, Engineer Allegedly Killed Over Opening Ceremony Glitch Make Winter Games Quite Bizarre |url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/538013/20140210/sochi-olympics.htm |newspaper=International Business Times |accessdate=25 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302115025/http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/538013/20140210/sochi-olympics.htm# |archive-date=2014-03-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> On 20 February, luger [[Kate Hansen]] posted a well-publicized video on her Twitter account allegedly showing a wolf roaming the hallways of her Sochi hotel; it was later revealed to be a hoax staged by talk show host [[Jimmy Kimmel]] and Hansen. USA Luge officials distanced themselves from the incident, with spokesman Sandy Caligiore stating, "I can tell you that our organization is not happy with the incident. Sochi problems? Sochi fail? That's not USA Luge speaking."<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=21 February 2014 |title=Olympic athlete's wolf video was part of hoax |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/sochi/2014/02/20/kate-hansen-usa-luge-wolf-hoax-jimmy-kimmel/5651913/ |newspaper=USA Today |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> Throughout the duration of the Olympics the @SochiProblems Twitter account had nearly 100,000 more followers than the official IOC feed @Sochi2014.<ref name="Sappenfield-Wallechinsky">{{cite news |last=Sappenfield |first=Mark |date=8 February 2014 |title=Are problems at Sochi Olympics being blown out of proportion? |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Olympics/2014/0208/Are-problems-at-Sochi-Olympics-being-blown-out-of-proportion-video |newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> The blog [https://web.archive.org/web/20141217051551/http://gossipsochi.com/ GossipSochi.com] was later set up to debunk @SochiProblems postings, with many revealed to be fakes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ilich |first=Bobby |date=22 February 2014 |title=Sochi Problems: Hold On, Wait... What Problems? |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/sochi-problems-hold-wait-what-problems-1557321 |newspaper=International Business Times |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Kibalchich2014">{{cite news |last=Kibalchich |first=Catherine |date=16 February 2014 |title=Олимпийские игры в Сочи широко обсуждаются в социальных сетях по всему |url=http://www.1tv.ru/news/sport/252386 |newspaper=Channel One |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
In an interview, IOC supervisor [[Jean-Claude Killy]] stated that several hotels intended to house the foreign media were unfinished by the opening of the Olympics because officials realized "too late" that construction had fallen behind.<ref name="Futterman&White2014">{{cite news |last1=Futterman |first1=Matthew |last2=White |first2=Gregory L. |date=17 February 2014 |title=Sochi Olympics Official: We Realized Hotel Problems 'Too Late' |url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304899704579388882111244174 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> According to [[David Wallechinsky]], president of the [[International Society of Olympic Historians]], many of the incidents early in the Olympics were "standard problems" and were not unique to Sochi. Wallechinsky further noted, "When you mess up with the media before the Games start, you're going to have a problem."<ref name="Sappenfield-Wallechinsky"/> In an interview that aired on Russian television on 24 February, Vladimir Putin opined that much of the criticism stemmed from rivalry in international politics, saying "There is a cohort of critics that are far from sport, they are engaged in a competitive struggle in international politics. They used this Olympic project to achieve their own objectives in the field of anti-Russian propaganda."<ref name="RIAsochicritics">{{cite news |date=25 February 2014 |title=Putin Says Sochi Criticism Motivated by Global Politics |url=http://en.ria.ru/sochi2014/20140225/187872611.html |agency=RIA Novosti |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
The mood greatly improved as the Games progressed.<ref name="McNamara2014">{{cite news |last=McNamara |first=Mary |date=12 February 2014 |title=Critic's Notebook: Sochi Games don't live down to the negative hype |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-critics-notebook-olympics-20140213,0,6862622.story |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Sun-Sentinel2014">{{cite news|date=24 February 2014 |title=As always, athletes made Olympics a joy |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/opinion/editorials/fl-editorial-olympics-gs0225-20140224,0,6007296.story |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140225175120/http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/opinion/editorials/fl-editorial-olympics-gs0225-20140224,0,6007296.story |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 February 2014 |newspaper=Sun-Sentinel |accessdate=25 February 2014 }}</ref> With a few notable exceptions, [[NBC]] largely avoided broadcasting negative material, although several segments deemed "overly friendly to Russia" were harshly criticized by some U.S. conservatives.<ref>{{cite news |last=Farhi |first=Paul |date=21 February 2014 |title=In coverage of Olympics, NBC has largely steered clear of controversy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/olympics/in-coverage-of-olympics-nbc-has-largely-steered-clear-of-controversy/2014/02/21/5e68a088-99aa-11e3-80ac-63a8ba7f7942_story.html |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> Following the [[2014 Winter Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]], Mark Sappenfield of ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' concluded that by many measures the Olympics were "very successful." Sappenfield singled out the organization as particularly good, writing that "Athletes and Olympic officials were nearly unanimous: This was an extraordinarily well run Olympics."<ref name="Sappenfield">{{cite news |last=Sappenfield |first=Mark |date=24 February 2014 |title=Sochi Olympics report card: So how good were Putin's Games? |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Olympics/2014/0224/Sochi-Olympics-report-card-So-how-good-were-Putin-s-Games-video |newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref> Thomas Bach also voiced support, stating "We saw excellent Games and what counts most is the opinions of the athletes and they were enormously satisfied...You have to ask all those who criticised whether they change their opinions now."<ref name="Grohmann2014">{{cite news |last=Grohmann |first=Karolos |date=23 February 2014 |title='Excellent' Sochi Games proved critics wrong, says IOC's Bach |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/23/olympics-sochi-bach-idINDEEA1M08W20140223 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=25 February 2014}}</ref>
==2014 Russian Formula One Grand Prix== In [[2014 Formula One season|2014]], Sochi hosted the [[Russian Grand Prix|Russian]] [[Formula One|Formula One Grand Prix]]. The [[Sochi Autodrom|circuit]] runs in and around the Sochi Olympic Park,<ref name="Russia in">{{cite news|title=Russia to join F1 calendar in 2014|url=http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/2010/10/14/russia-to-join-f1-calendar-in-2014/|first=Keith|last=Collantine|work=F1 Fanatic|publisher=Keith Collantine|date=14 October 2010|accessdate=25 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="OMEGA">{{cite news|title=OMEGA|url=http://www.omega2014.ru/projects/formula1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109232353/http://www.omega2014.ru/projects/formula1|archivedate=2011-11-09|publisher=OMEGA (Developer)|accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref> which led to the [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] expressing concern that construction of the circuit could disrupt preparations for the Olympic Games. The IOC was granted the power to delay the inaugural race until 2015 in order to ensure the Olympics were held without disruption,<ref name="IOC warns">{{cite news|title=IOC threatens to postpone Russian Grand Prix|url=http://www.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/250388/ioc-threatens-to-postpone-russian-grand-prix/|work=GP Update|date=13 January 2011|accessdate=6 April 2012}}</ref> but did not use it as competition was not disrupted.
==Countries choosing not to enter competitors== A total of 91 nations qualified to compete at the Games. However, three nations chose not to send their athletes to the Games, even though they had met the international qualification standards.
[[Puerto Rico]] is not sending [[Kristina Krone]] for the second consecutive time because the [[Puerto Rico Olympic Committee]] (COPUR) withdrew its recognition of the Puerto Rico Winter Sports Federation after the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] due to an eligibility controversy involving a member of their bobsled team. According to COPUR president [[Sara Rosario]], "Until there is a properly constituted winter sports federation with the requisite seriousness upon which we can consistently rely every four years, we cannot endorse (participation by Puerto Rico athletes in the Olympic Winter Games)".<ref>{{cite news |last=Pagan Rivera |first=Esteban |date=12 January 2014 |title=Kristina Krone: Quería ir a Sochi, pero nunca recibió contestación del Comité Olímpico |url=http://www.primerahora.com/deportes/otros/nota/kristinakronequeriairasochiperonuncarecibiocontestaciondelcomiteolimpico-982330/ |language=Spanish |newspaper=Primerahora |location= |publisher= |accessdate=12 January 2014 |quote=Hasta que no haya un proyecto con la seriedad que requiere y una federación de deportes de invierno realmente constituida, a la cual podamos estar pendientes de ellos cada cuatro años de manera consistente, no podemos avalar}}</ref> Krone has represented [[Puerto Rico]] since 2008 in more than 100 alpine ski competitions sanctioned by the [[International Ski Federation]] including the 2009, 2011 and 2013 [[World Alpine Ski Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.fis-ski.com/dynamic/athlete-biography.html?sector=AL&competitorid=149881&type=result&bt=prev&limit=50&bt=prev&rec_start=0 |title=KRONE Kristina – Biographie |publisher=Data.fis-ski.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref>
[[South Africa]] would not enter skier [[Sive Speelman]], who, although invited to compete by the IOC, did not meet the standards set by the [[South African Sports Confederation and Olympic Committee]].<ref>{{cite news |title=South Africa withdraws only athlete|url=http://espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2014/alpine/story/_/id/10343352/south-africa-denies-only-olympian-sive-speelman-place-sochi |accessdate=January 24, 2014 |newspaper=Associated Press|date=January 24, 2014}}</ref>
[[Algeria]] also chose not to enter its only competitor, [[Mehdi-Selim Khelifi]], because he was the only one that managed to qualify, even though he was their only entry four years prior at the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] in [[Vancouver]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Dubault |first=Fabrice |date=24 January 2014 |title=L'histoire invraisemblable de Mehdi Khelifi privé de J.O par l'Algérie |url=http://languedoc-roussillon.france3.fr/2014/01/24/l-histoire-invraisemblable-de-mehdi-khelifi-prive-de-jo-par-l-algerie-401707.html |newspaper=[[France 3]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=24 January 2014 }}</ref>
==Independent participants== There were three [[Independent Olympic Athletes at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Independent Olympic participants]] from [[India]] who competed under the Olympics flag. In December 2012, the [[Indian Olympic Association]] was suspended by the [[IOC]] due to government interference in the autonomy and election of leaders, thus not complying with the [[Olympic charter]]. Fresh elections were due to take place after the opening ceremony so Indian athletes were scheduled to participate as independents.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Shiva Kesavan hopes India's suspension lifted before Sochi Olympics |url=http://olympics.cbc.ca/news/article/shiva-kesavan-hopes-india-suspension-lifted-before-sochi-olympics-30984.html |newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |location= |agency=Associated Press |date=18 December 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140129111156/http://olympics.cbc.ca/news/article/shiva-kesavan-hopes-india-suspension-lifted-before-sochi-olympics-30984.html |archivedate=29 January 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref name="d">{{cite news |last= |first= |date=10 January 2014 |title=Three Indians to take part in Sochi Winter Games |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tournaments/2014-sochi-winter-olympics/Three-Indians-to-take-part-in-Sochi-Winter-Games/articleshow/28596848.cms |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=10 January 2014 }}</ref>
==Course adjustments== A crash in practice from Norwegian [[slopestyle]] snowboarder [[Torstein Horgmo]], who fractured his collarbone, and complaints from other athletes that some jumps were too steep have prompted organizers to modify the slopestyle course in the week before the Games.<ref>{{cite news | title=Sochi Snowboarding Course Deemed Too Dangerous After Accident| url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/sochi2014/Sochi-Snowboarding-Course-Deemed-Too-Dangerous-After-Accident.html |publisher= The Moscow Times| date=3 February 2014| accessdate=3 February 2014 }}</ref> A few days later the women's downhill ski training was stopped after the opening three racers were getting too much air on the jump down the home stretch. The International Ski Federation had workers adjusting the course making it smoother.<ref>{{cite news | title=Fenninger tops in Olympic downhill training run| url=http://www.kansas.com/2014/02/06/3270531/womens-training-run-delayed-after.html#storylink=cpy| archive-url=https://archive.is/20140206154818/http://www.kansas.com/2014/02/06/3270531/womens-training-run-delayed-after.html| dead-url=yes| archive-date=6 February 2014|publisher= kansas.com| date=6 February 2014| accessdate=6 February 2014 }}</ref>
==Inadequate preparation of visitor facilities== In the week prior to the start of the Games, reports began coming out of Sochi that a number of the accommodations for visitors and journalists were still incomplete. Several hotels meant to house visitors to the Games were reported to be still under construction upon arrival, as well as missing basic furniture from some of the rooms that had finished construction. The issues forced a number of visitors to seek alternate accommodations. Other problems reported included "piles of garbage" on the streets of the media village, as well as significant construction noise.<ref>{{cite news |publisher= The Telegraph (London) |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/10620602/Winter-Olympics-visitors-complain-about-Sochi-construction-sites.html |title= Winter Olympics visitors complain about Sochi 'construction sites' |date= 5 February 2014 }}</ref>
Other notable incidents:
* [[Johnny Quinn]], member of the US bobsled team, became trapped in his bathroom and had to bash a hole in the door to get out.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/09/world/europe/olympics-us-bobsledder-bathroom/ |title= Trapped in Sochi bathroom, bobsledder punches hole in door |author= Faith Karimi |date= 10 February 2014 |publisher= CNN }}</ref> Two days later and his teammates [[Nick Cunningham]] and [[Nick Cripps]] became trapped in an elevator.<ref name=DailyMail-2014-02-11-elevator>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/winterolympics/article-2556318/American-bobsledder-Johnny-Quinn-gets-stuck-elevator-just-two-days-breaking-way-hotel-bathroom-Sochi.html |title= American bobsledder Quinn gets stuck in an elevator just two days after breaking his way out of hotel bathroom in Sochi |author= John Drayton |date= 11 February 2014 |publisher= Daily Mail (London) }}</ref> * [[Rebekah Wilson]], member of the British bobsled team, experienced having elevator doors open onto an empty elevator shaft.<ref name=DailyMail-2014-02-11-elevator/> * Stacy St. Clair, [[Chicago Tribune]] reporter, reported that her hotel had no water, and that staff informed her that when it returned, not to wash her face in it as it was dangerous. The water service that returned provided murky dark water. The "dangerous face water" incident went viral.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-02-04/news/chi-sochi-dangerous-water-20140204_1_sochi-clair-dangerous-water |title= Sochi hotel tells our reporter: Don't let dangerous water touch your face |date= 4 February 2014 |publisher= Chicago Tribune |author= Scott Kleinberg }}</ref>
==Use of mourning symbols== During the [[Cross-country skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's 15 kilometre skiathlon|women's 15 kilometre skiathlon]] four Norwegian skiers used black mourning binds in honor of teammate [[Astrid Uhrenholdt Jacobsen]]'s brother who had died unexpectedly on the opening day of the Olympics. IOC sent a reminder to the [[Norwegian Olympic Committee]] (NOC) that using mourning binds was not allowed during the games.<ref name=cob>Stephen Wilson (10 February 2014) [https://web.archive.org/web/20140221210305/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2014/02/10/4679484/ioc-reprimands-athletes-for-commemorating.html#.UvquorRSOp0 IOC: Black armbands, helmet stickers not allowed] AP Sports. ''[[Charlotte Observer]]''. Retrieved 11 February 2014</ref> IOC's letter caused protests in Norway and Sweden.<ref>Daniel Røed-Johansen (10 February 2014) [http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/mesterskap/Jeg-haper-samtlige-lopere-kommer-til-start-med-sorgeband---for-a-markere-mot-IOC-418103_1.snd#.Uvqzl7RSOp0 Jeg håper samtlige løpere kommer til start med sørgebånd - for å markere mot IOC] {{no icon}} ''[[Aftenposten]]''. Retrieved 11 February 2014</ref> NOC general secretary Inge Andersen met with IOC president [[Thomas Bach]] to discuss the matter on 10 February 2014. Norway's IOC member [[Gerhard Heiberg]] indicated that IOC would reconsider the ban against mourning binds.<ref>Mette Bugge (11 February 2014) [http://www.aftenposten.no/100Sport/mesterskap/IOC-snur-i-sorgebandsaken-418310_1.snd#.Uvq10rRSOp1 IOC snur i sørgebåndsaken] {{no icon}} ''[[Aftenposten]]''. Retrieved 11 February 2014</ref>
Freestyle skiers were told by IOC not to wear helmet stickers in memory of [[Sarah Burke]], who died in an accident in 2012.<ref name=cob/> However, many still did, and the rule was believed to not have been enforced.
On 19 February [[Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics|Ukrainian athletes]] asked for and were refused permission by the IOC to wear black arm bands to honor those killed [[February 2014 Euromaidan riots|in the violent clashes in Kiev the previous day]].<ref name=R19214Umb>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/19/us-olympics-idUSBREA1G0GL20140219 Hockey heartache for hosts, Ukraine violence shocks Games], [[Reuters]] (19 February 2014)</ref> According to IOC spokesman Mark Adams "They weren't forbidden to wear armbands. The [[National Olympic Committee of Ukraine|Ukrainian NOC]] met with IOC officials informally yesterday. They discussed what should be done, and they reached the conclusion there were other ways of marking this moment. Some athletes have taken other views and other ways of doing things".<ref name="SUlGR20214">[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/02/20/uk-olympics-ukraine-idUKBREA1J0EI20140220 Some Ukraine team members leave Games – IOC], [[Reuters]] (20 February 2014)</ref> IOC president Bach offered his condolences "to those who have lost loved ones in these tragic events".<ref name=R19214Umb/>
==Athlete boycott== On 19 February 2014 [[Ukrainia]]n [[alpine skier]] [[Bohdana Matsotska]] refused to further participate in the Olympic Games in protest of the violent clashes in Kiev on the previous day.<ref name="SUlGR20214"/><ref name=KPBS19214>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/sport/ukrainian-olympic-alpine-skier-quits-sochi-blames-yanukovych-for-deaths-on-euromaidan-337181.html Ukrainian Olympic alpine skier quits Sochi, blames Yanukovych for deaths on EuroMaidan], [[Kyiv Post]] (19 February 2014)</ref> She and her father posted a message on [[Facebook]] stating "In solidarity with the fighters on the barricades of the Maidan, and as a protest against the criminal actions made towards the protesters, the irresponsibility of the [[Viktor Yanukovych|president]] and [[Second Azarov Government|his lackey government]], we refuse further performance at the Olympic Games in Sochi 2014".<ref name=KPBS19214/>
On 20 February 2014 the [[National Olympic Committee of Ukraine|Ukrainian NOC]] reported that as many as half of the [[Ukraine at the 2014 Winter Olympics|45 Ukrainian athletes at the Olympics]] had left the games to return home.<ref name="UkraineBBC20214">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26268620 Ukraine death toll rises to 22 as EU talks under way], [[BBC News]] (20 February 2014)</ref> But according to Ukrainian NOC president [[Sergey Bubka]] they had returned home in compliance with their original schedule, and their departure was thus not related to the riots in [[Kiev]].<ref name="BUOTsWP20214">[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/feb/20/bogdana-matsotska-ukraine-withdraws-olympics-after/?page=2 Ukrainian skier pulls out of Olympics, says country's president should be ‘jailed’], [[The Washington Times]] (20 February 2014)</ref>
==Drug tests== During the 2014 Winter Olympics, six athletes tested positive for banned substances and were sent home from the Games.
On 21 February, skier [[Evi Sachenbacher-Stehle]] of Germany and Italian bobsleigh brakeman [[William Frullani]] were both sent home from Sochi after failing drugs tests. They both tested positive for [[methylhexanamine]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/winter-olympics/26289156 |title=Sochi 2014: German athlete fails A sample drugs test |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 February 2014}}</ref> On 22 February, Ukrainian cross-country skier [[Marina Lisogor]] was tested positive for [[trimetazidine]] and Latvian ice hockey player [[Vitalijs Pavlovs]] tested positive for methylhexaneamine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/winter-olympics/26304664 |title=Sochi 2014: Ukraine's Marina Lisogor fails drugs test |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 February 2014}}</ref> On 23 February, Austrian skier [[Johannes Dürr]] tested positive for [[Erythropoietin|EPO]] and Swedish ice hockey player [[Nicklas Bäckström]] tested positive for a substance found in an allergy medication.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/winter-olympics/26312069 |title=Sochi 2014: Nicklas Backstrom & Johannes Duerr test positive |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 February 2014}}</ref>
==Men's freestyle skiing – ski cross== Both [[Canada]] and [[Slovenia]] appealed separately to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] that the three [[France|French]] athletes in the Big Final of the [[Freestyle skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's ski cross|men's ski cross]] final had their pants illegally changed by their coach. They argued it gave the three an aerodynamic advantage over the rest of the field. Both countries first appealed to the [[International Ski Federation]], but were rejected since they appealed hours after the end of the competition (when the deadline was 15 minutes after the close of the race). The appeal to the court was ultimately unsuccessful as well, because the court agreed with the ski federation that the appeal was filed past the deadline.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Canada's skicross appeal over altered pants dismissed|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/sochi2014/2014/02/23/canadas_skicross_appeal_over_altered_pants_dismissed.html |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |location=[[Sochi]], [[Russia]] |publisher=[[Toronto Star]] |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate= March 2014 }}</ref>
==Russian Mafia used to threaten rival campaign allegations== The Russian mafia helped Russia win the games by threatening the Salzburg campaign leader Fedor Radmann, who later resigned in 2007, according to German security officials.<ref name=faz_26_05_2014/> Informants observed a meeting between mafia leaders and Russian government foreign policy advisor [[Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko|Sergei Prikhodko]] in 2006 in a [[Munich]] restaurant to discuss the Olympic selection process.<ref name=faz_26_05_2014/> Radmann himself denies he ever met any Russian mobsters but his colleagues state that he feared for his life, and the mayor of Salzburg [[Heinz Schaden]] confirms the link.<ref name=faz_26_05_2014>{{cite news|title=Holte die Russen-Mafia die Spiele nach Sotschi?|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/sport/sportpolitik/olympische-winterspiele-holte-die-russen-mafia-die-spiele-nach-sotschi-12956711.html|accessdate=26 May 2014|newspaper=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Russen-Mafia soll bei Sotschi-Bewerbung geholfen haben|url=http://www.focus.de/sport/olympia-2014/andere-olympia-bewerber-unter-druck-gesetzt-russen-mafia-soll-bei-sotschi-bewerbung-geholfen-haben_id_3870510.html|accessdate=11 June 2014|work=[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]]|publisher=[[Helmut Markwort]]|date=2014-05-25|ref=focus_25may2014}}</ref><ref name=wirtschaftsblatt_260514>{{cite news|title=Sotschi statt Salzburg: War die Mafia im Spiel?|url=http://wirtschaftsblatt.at/home/life/sport/3812017/Sotschi-statt-Salzburg_War-die-Mafia-im-Spiel|accessdate=11 June 2014|work=[[WirtschaftsBlatt]]|issue=26.05.2014|publisher=Wirtschaftsblatt Verlag AG}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Concerns and controversies at the 2010 Winter Olympics]] * [[Concerns and controversies at the 2012 Summer Olympics]] *[[List of 2018 FIFA World Cup controversies]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Portalbar|Olympics|Russia|Human rights}}

[[Category:2014 controversies]] [[Category:2014 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic Games controversies|*2014]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Russia]] [[Category:Doping in Russia]]

{{Infobox company | name = Daystate | logo = Daystate logo.png | type = Private Limited | foundation = 1978 | location = [[Eccleshall]], Staffordshire | key_people = Mauro Marocchi, Gianbattista Sabatti, Rachel Eyre | industry = Sporting, [[Hunting]] | products = [[Air rifle]] | revenue = | num_employees = | homepage = [http://www.daystate.com/ www.daystate.com] }} '''Daystate''' is a manufacturer of [[Air rifle]]s based in [[Eccleshall]], [[Staffordshire]] in the United Kingdom.
==History== The enterprise was founded in 1978 by Don Lowndes, Jim Phillips, Ken Gibbon and Mike Seddon with the aim of making tranquilliser guns for pest control purposes. The first product was the Air Ranger.<ref name="The Daystate Saga – Part 1 Getting started">{{cite web|url=http://www.pyramydair.com/blog/2007/08/the-daystate-saga-part-1-getting-started/|publisher=Pyramyd Air|accessdate=14 August 2014|title=The Daystate Saga – Part 1 Getting started}}</ref>
In 1980 Daystate was commissioned by [[Rentokil]] to manufacture a small bore rifle for pest control, this model was named the [[Daystate Huntsman|Huntsman]] and is in manufacture until today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daystate.com/huntsman.htm|publisher=Daystate|title="Huntsman Regal // Retro Styling in a modern sporter guise"|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>
In the mid 1980's Daystate was building PCP air rifles for the general public, at this time all rifles were built by hand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pneumatic Masters|url=http://content.yudu.com/Library/A1s9b0/AirgunShooterJuly201/resources/content/48.swf|publisher=Airgun Shooter|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref>
==Product Lines==
Daystate currently produce 8 core products with various options in terms of calibre, stock and finish.
===Current Models=== •Pulsar •Wolverine2 •Wolverine R •Renegade R •HR Huntsman Regal •Griffin •Tsar •Red Wolf
===Past Models=== *Harrier *Harrier X *LR90 *Merlyn *MK3 *PH6 *Wolverine *X2 *Grand Prix *2000 *QC *Huntsman FTR *Competa target pistol *Airwolf CDT *Airwolf MCT *Air Ranger
==References== {{Reflist}}
