[[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport, LA]] 71109 | coordinates = | opened = 1986 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Shreveport, Louisiana|City of Shreveport]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Shreveport Captains]] ([[Texas League|TL]]) (1986–2000)
[[Shreveport Swamp Dragons]] (TL) (2001–2002)
[[Shreveport-Bossier Sports]] ([[Central Baseball League|CBL]]/[[American Association of Independent Professional Baseball|AA]]) (2003–2008)
[[Shreveport-Bossier Captains]] (AA) (2009–2011) | seating_capacity = 4,200 | dimensions = }} '''Fair Grounds Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]], located next to [[Independence Stadium (Shreveport)|Independence Stadium]] on the Louisiana State Fair Grounds just off [[Interstate 20]]. Fair Grounds Field opened in 1986 and underwent renovations in 1999, 2009, and 2011. The stadium has a [[seating capacity]] of 4,200 people. Fair Grounds Field currently does not have a primary tenant. In the past it has most notably served as the home field of the [[Shreveport Captains]], [[Shreveport Swamp Dragons]], [[Shreveport-Bossier Sports]], and [[Shreveport-Bossier Captains]] [[minor league]] and independent baseball teams. Fair Grounds Field hosted the 1986 and 1995 [[Texas League]] All-Star Games, 2004 [[The Summit League Baseball Tournament|Summit League Baseball Tournament]], and 2011 [[Southwestern Athletic Conference Baseball Tournament]].{{cite web|url=http://www.swac.org/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=27400&ATCLID=205398796|title=2010-11 Championships|publisher=SWAC.org|accessdate=2012-03-27}} Fair Grounds Field has hosted many college baseball teams including [[LSU Tigers baseball|LSU]], [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs baseball|Louisiana Tech]], [[Northwestern State Demons|Northwestern State]], [[Centenary Gentlemen|Centenary]], and [[Louisiana State University in Shreveport|LSU–Shreveport]]. The facility has also been used by local high school baseball teams. == References == {{reflist}} {{coord|32.478350|-93.783057|display=title|type:landmark}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Shreveport, Louisiana]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Louisiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1986]] {{Louisiana-baseball-venue-stub}}

page.title: Greg LeMond anti-doping stance and controversies

revision.text:
[[File:Greg-LeMond-2009 (2).jpg|thumbnail|right|195px|Greg LeMond addresses Play the Game 2009 conference.]] Considered one of the most successful cyclists of his generation, [[Greg LeMond]] competed at a time when [[doping (sport)|performance-enhancing drugs]] [[List_of_doping_cases_in_cycling#1980s|were well known in his sport]], including blood doping at the 1984 LA Olympics. {{cite web|title=History of doping in cycling: http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Performance-Enhancing_Drugs.aspx}}{{cite web|title="Clean cycling is an illusion”, Francesco Moser one hour record holder from 1984: http://www.dailypeloton.com/displayarticle.asp?pk=10163 |date=July 2015}} Lemond claims that from his earliest days of professional cycling, he was strongly against taking drugs to alter performance (although there are few records of him speaking out during his career), and his career is not as tarnished by suspicions as his contemporaries or successors. His willingness (after his career) to speak out against doping and those prominent individuals involved in it (primarily Lance Armstrong) ended up inadvertently linking him with the sport’s [[Doping in cycling|doping scandal]] controversies.{{cite web|last=Tinley|first=Josh|title=Bummed About Lance Armstrong? There’s Always Greg LeMond|url=http://www.midwestsportsfans.com/2012/08/bummed-about-lance-armstrong-theres-always-greg-lemond/|publisher=Midwest Sports Fans (MSF)|accessdate=14 December 2012|date=24 August 2012|quote=Greg LeMond has never been accused or suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs. But his legacy and credibility are linked to the sport’s doping scandals because he has been so outspoken on the topic.}} In his opposition to fraud, corruption and what he saw as complicity on the part of cycling officials, LeMond became a lightning rod of sorts for the sports most prominent personalities.{{cite web|last=Slater|first=Matt|title=Greg LeMond ready to help cycling's post-Armstrong clean-up|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/20602191|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 December 2012|date=5 December 2012}}{{#tag:ref|"What LeMond has in buckets is authenticity. Unlike Armstrong, he is a real all-American hero. LeMond did it clean. Blessed with a remarkable engine, the "LeMonster" could climb, race, time-trial, and do it all over again the following day. He was a phenomenon and is unlucky to have won only three Tour titles. Already a world road race champion, he came third in his Tour debut in 1984, despite riding in support of victorious Frenchman Laurent Fignon."|group=N}} In 2001 LeMond was one of the first professional cyclists of note, and the only former Tour champion, to openly express doubts over the legitimacy of Lance Armstrong's three-consecutive Tour successes.{{cite web|last=Slater|first=Matt|title=Greg LeMond joins Change Cycling Now to clean up the sport|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/20542662|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 December 2012|date=29 November 2012|quote=The involvement of LeMond, who voiced his suspicions about Armstrong long before he was stripped of his seven Tour de France titles by the UCI, is a coup for CCN as he is one of a select group of recent Tour champions to be untarnished by allegations of drug use. The 51-year-old Californian has been increasingly outspoken in recent years about the UCI's failure to address the culture of doping that has so badly damaged cycling's credibility, and last month he called for UCI president Pat McQuaid to resign.}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2001/jul/30/cycling.cycling1|last=Fotheringham|first=William|title=Drugs issue refuses to go away due to winner's Ferrari links|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=29 July 2001|quote=The rumblings about Lance Armstrong's work with the controversial Italian trainer Michele Ferrari continued yesterday, when Greg LeMond, a triple winner of the Tour, summed up the feelings of many on this Tour in saying: "When Lance won the prologue to the 1999 Tour I was close to tears, but when I heard he was working with Michele Ferrari I was devastated. In the light of Lance's relationship with Ferrari, I just don't want to comment on this year's Tour. This is not sour grapes. I'm disappointed in Lance, that's all it is."|location=London}}{{cite news|title=Two champions - Armstrong surprised, upset by LeMond's comments|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/cycling/news/2001/08/02/armstrong_lemond_ap/|publisher=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=2 August 2001|quote=Armstrong said he had spoken to LeMond, the only other American to win cycling's most prestigious event three times and the first American to win it at all, about comments LeMond made earlier this week on Armstrong's relationship with physician Michele Ferrari. LeMond had told the Guardian, a London newspaper, "In the light of Lance's relationship with Ferrari, I just don't want to comment on this year's Tour. This is not sour grapes. I'm just disappointed in Lance."}} He has consistently questioned the relationship between riders and sports doctors like the Italian [[Michele Ferrari]]. Ferrari was ultimately banned for life by the [[United States Anti-Doping Agency]] in July 2012 for his association with doping.{{cite news|title=USADA issues lifetime bans to del Moral, Ferrari and Marti|url=http://www.cyclingweekly.co.uk/news/latest/533828/usada-issues-lifetime-bans-to-del-moral-ferrari-and-marti.html|newspaper=Cycling Weekly}} In 2006 LeMond noted that the extent of doping in the sport could not occur without complicity from the body that regulates international professional cycling, and he accused the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] of serious doping-related corruption.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDy5NLVkliU&feature=related Greg LeMond - 'Cycling is dying through Drugs' at Play the Game Conference], 27:00 and 44:00 Play the Game Conference, Coventry University, 2009 Jun 12, retr 2012 10 14[http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/ucis-failure-to-silence-lemond UCI's failure to silence LeMond], Daniel Benson and Susan Westemeyer, Cycling News, October 4, 2012 In an open letter in December 2012 he asserted that UCI's [[Pat McQuaid]] and [[Hein Verbruggen]] were central to the problem in professional cycling.{{cite web|url=http://nyvelocity.com/content/features/2012/open-letter-pat-mcquaid-greg-lemond|last=LeMond|first=Greg|title=Open Letter to Pat McQuaid from Greg LeMond|publisher=NYVelocity.com|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=25 October 2012|quote=Pat in my opinion you and Hein are the corrupt part of the sport. I do not want to include everyone at the UCI because I believe that there are many, maybe most that work at the UCI that are dedicated to cycling, they do it out of the love of the sport, but you and your buddy Hein have destroyed the sport.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122063725/http://nyvelocity.com/content/features/2012/open-letter-pat-mcquaid-greg-lemond|archivedate=22 November 2012|df=}} LeMond claimed professional cyclists are treated as "lab rats," while the doping facilitators escape harm or responsibility. He told an audience at Coventry University, "The doctors, the management, the officials, they're the ones that have corrupted riders. The riders are the only ones that pay the price". LeMond's statements have brought him into conflict with some of the sport's elite, including the UCI's McQuaid and Verbruggen, the [[Trek Bicycle Corporation]],{{cite news|last=Albergotti|first=Reed|title=Feud Sends Cycling World Spinning Eight-Year-Old Dispute Between Armstrong, LeMond Could Be Headed to a Courtroom|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124459634335000647|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=10 June 2009|quote=The battle between the two men has been playing out in federal district court in Minnesota, where Mr. LeMond is suing the bicycle maker Trek alleging breach of contract -- claiming, in part, that Mr. Armstrong was responsible for Trek's alleged neglect of Mr. LeMond's signature line of bikes.}} and riders [[Lance Armstrong]],{{cite news|last=Albergotti|first=Reed|title=Feud Sends Cycling World Spinning Eight-Year-Old Dispute Between Armstrong, LeMond Could Be Headed to a Courtroom|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124459634335000647|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=10 June 2009|quote=In August 2001, former professional cyclist George Mount was about to hop on his bike and embark on a leisurely ride in Northern California with his friend, three-time Tour de France winner Greg LeMond, when Mr. LeMond got a call on his mobile phone. It was Lance Armstrong, America's other legendary cyclist. According to Mr. Mount, Mr. Armstrong had read comments Mr. LeMond had made about him in an article about doping allegations in the Guardian newspaper, where Mr. LeMond was quoted as saying he was "disappointed" with Mr. Armstrong's association with a controversial Italian doctor. When Mr. Armstrong was done ripping into Mr. LeMond on the phone that day, Mr. Mount recalled, Mr. LeMond looked "like somebody had walked up and slapped him."}} [[Floyd Landis]], and [[Alberto Contador]]. In the interests of reforming the sport, LeMond offered to serve as president of the UCI, taking over the position of former president Pat McQuaid.{{cite news|last=Seaton|first=Matt|title=Is Greg LeMond the right choice to challenge for the UCI presidency?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2012/dec/03/greg-lemond-cycling-uci-presidency|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=10 December 2012|quote=With Armstrong discredited by the Usada report, set in motion by the revelations of former team-mates Floyd Landis and Tyler Hamilton, the reformers see an epochal opportunity to usher in a new era of transparency, of credible anti-doping controls, and of stability in the sport that constantly risks the loss of vital sponsors through the drip-drip of the past decade and a half's dope-cheating scandals – from the Festina affair in 1998, through the Operation Puerto investigation, the Team Telekom/T-Mobile confessions, right up to this year's dramatic events. As LeMond said: "It is now or never to act. After the earthquake caused by the Armstrong case, another chance will not arise. I am willing to invest to make this institution more democratic, transparent and look for the best candidate in the longer term."|location=London|date=December 3, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Slater|first=Matt|title=Greg LeMond ready to help cycling's post-Armstrong clean-up|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/20602191|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 December 2012|date=5 December 2012|quote=That temporary custodian could then implement CCN's plan for a "Truth and Reconciliation Commission", an investigation of the UCI during the Armstrong era, and push forward with the creation of an independent body to run the sport's anti-doping regime. LeMond races to victory in the 1989 Tour de France "I was cornered and forced into saying yes, I'd do it, if there was nobody else," LeMond said, with palpable embarrassment. "The goal of the group is change and there are people out there who would make great presidents of the UCI. I'm not certain I would, but I would be willing to do it temporarily. "I'd prefer to be part of the group that looks at how you can return transparency and credibility to the sport, but if that requires an interim position, well, I would love to be part of the process." In truth, the American is unlikely to become president of the UCI, temporarily or otherwise. McQuaid shows no signs of stepping down voluntarily, while LeMond has no real powerbase and only limited contact with today's riders.}} ==UCI and Pat McQuaid== [[File:Patrick McQuaid.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Former UCI President Pat McQuaid]] In around 2006, LeMond had described [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI) as "corrupt" in an interview in ''[[L'Équipe]]'' about doping in the sport. In response the [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] and [[Pat McQuaid]] threatened to sue him for defamation in Switzerland. In 2007 LeMond, inspired by a positive experience at [[L'Étape du Tour]], felt that perhaps the [[Tour de France]] could start a clean-up in the sport by separating from UCI. He made his feelings known to [[Patrice Clerc]] and [[Christian Prudhomme]]. LeMond soon after received a letter from UCI's [[Pat McQuaid]] threatening him with another lawsuit. [[File:BRIAN COOKSON.jpg|thumb|right|170px|British Cycling president Brian Cookson]] Following the [[United States Anti-Doping Agency]] findings against [[Lance Armstrong]] and U.S. Postal Service in 2012,{{cite news|url=http://www.usada.org/media/sanction-armstrong8242012|title=Lance Armstrong Receives Lifetime Ban And Disqualification Of Competitive Results For Doping Violations Stemming From His Involvement In The United States Postal Service Pro-Cycling Team Doping Conspiracy|publisher=USADA |date=August 24, 2012|accessdate=October 21, 2012}} LeMond stated that a change needed to be made at the head of leadership for the UCI, and stated if called upon he would be willing to take the position himself if necessary to lead cycling out of the mire of doping. Said LeMond: "It is now or never to act. After the earthquake caused by the Armstrong case, another chance will not arise. I am willing to invest to make this institution more democratic, transparent and look for the best candidate in the longer term."{{cite news|last=Seaton|first=Matt|title=Is Greg LeMond the right choice to challenge for the UCI presidency?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2012/dec/03/greg-lemond-cycling-uci-presidency|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=10 December 2012|location=London|date=December 3, 2012}} Lemond came to support British Cycling president Brian Cookson in the UCI Presidential battle. Said Lemond: “I have met and spent some time discussing with Brian about where cycling lost its way, how it lost its way, and what to do to bring the sport back to where it is not only a sport that leads by example, but a sport that inspires people once again. I feel confident after meeting Brian that his interest is to bring honest and transparent leadership to a sport that so desperately needs it. My hope is Brian will be the one to bring all interested parties together to once and for all do what was needed to be done years before, find solutions, both short term and long term, and to make it a priority that cycling comes first, not the other way around.”{{cite web|last=Stokes|first=Shane|title=Triple Tour de France winner Greg LeMond backs Brian Cookson in UCI Presidential battle|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/15372/Triple-Tour-de-France-winner-Greg-LeMond-backs-Brian-Cookson-in-UCI-Presidential-battle.aspx|date=August 31, 2013|accessdate=January 27, 2015}} Cookson defeated McQuaid at the September 2013 UCI Congress in Florence, Italy.{{cite web|last=Hood|first=Andrew|title=Cookson wins UCI presidency after Machiavellian drama|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2013/09/analysis/cookson-wins-uci-presidency-after-machiavellian-drama_304290|date=September 27, 2013|accessdate=January 26, 2015}} ==Lance Armstrong and Trek== [[File:NIH-lancearm2.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Lance Armstrong]] In July 2001, LeMond criticized [[Lance Armstrong]] for associating with [[Michele Ferrari]], an Italian physician and sports trainer who admitted to practicing [[blood doping]] and advocated the controlled use of the banned substance [[erythropoietin]] by athletes. Ferrari has been accused by professional cyclists of providing banned substances.{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/cycling/news/2001/08/02/armstrong_lemond_ap |publisher=CNN | title=Armstrong surprised, upset by LeMond's comments | accessdate=May 4, 2010}}[http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/riders/2003/interviews/?id=ferrari03 www.cyclingnews.com news and analysis]. Autobus.cyclingnews.com. Retrieved on August 21, 2011.[http://www.bicycling.com/tourdefrance/article/0,6802,s-3-12-13773-1-P,00.html Paging Doctor Ferrari] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100418135213/http://www.bicycling.com/tourdefrance/article/0%2C6802%2Cs-3-12-13773-1-P%2C00.html |date=2010-04-18 }}. Bicycling.com. Retrieved on August 21, 2011.[http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/news/2002/feb02/feb13news.php www.cyclingnews.com news and analysis]. Autobus.cyclingnews.com (February 13, 2002). Retrieved on August 21, 2011.
"When Lance won the prologue to the 1999 Tour I was close to tears, but when I heard he was working with Michele Ferrari I was devastated. In the light of Lance's relationship with Ferrari, I just don't want to comment on this year's Tour. This is not sour grapes. I'm disappointed in Lance, that's all it is."[http://sport.guardian.co.uk/cycling/story/0,10482,529487,00.html Drugs issue refuses to go away due to winner's Ferrari links]. ''The Guardian''. Retrieved on August 21, 2011.
Ferrari was charged with abuse of his medical license for writing prescriptions for banned substances and with sporting fraud. An Italian appeals court acquitted Ferrari, finding "the facts (to support the charges) do not exist".[http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/news.php?id=news/2006/may06/may27news Michele Ferrari absolved of all charges by Italian appeals court"], ''CyclingNews'', May 27, 2006 Nevertheless, Ferrari was later banned from the sport by [[USADA]]. Following LeMond's 2001 statement, Trek threatened LeMond with litigation and financial consequences, according to a 2008 lawsuit by LeMond Cycles against Trek. Trek had been licensing LeMond cycles since the 1990s and the brand had become successful. Armstrong's business relationship with Trek had become very strong as well after his Tour victories. [http://www.trekbikes.com/pdf/media/en/03202008_Lemond.pdf Complaint, LeMond Cycling Inc, vs Trek Bicycle Corporation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516211557/http://www.trekbikes.com/pdf/media/en/03202008_Lemond.pdf |date=2008-05-16 }}, 2008 3 20, retr 2012 10 13. from trekbikes.com. Armstrong reportedly said privately he could "shut him up" by contacting Trek, as documented in affidavits by [[Frankie Andreu|Frankie and Betsy Andreu]] released in the 2012 [[USADA]] doping report.[http://cyclinginvestigation.usada.org/ Statement of Travis Tygart of the USADA on US Postal Team] USADA v. Lance Armstrong, Oct 2012, pages 53-54.[http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/sports/173572821.html Lance Armstrong and his ties to Trek], Don Walker, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, The Business of Sports. Oct 10 2012. About a month later, in August 2001, LeMond issued an apology for his comment, calling Armstrong "a great champion and I do not believe, in any way, that he has ever used any performance-enhancing substances. I believe his performances are the result of the same hard work, dedication and focus that were mine 10 years ago."[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2001/08/14/lemond010814.html LeMond clarifies Armstrong criticisms]. Cbc (Canada) (August 14, 2001). Retrieved on August 21, 2011. Three years later, in 2004, LeMond spoke out again. On the heels of successive Tour de France wins by Armstrong, LeMond stated: "If Armstrong's clean, it's the greatest comeback. And if he's not, then it's the greatest fraud." He went public with the fallout of his 2001 statement, alleging that Armstrong had threatened to defame him, and threatened his business interests as well:
"[Armstrong] basically said 'I could find 10 people that will say you took EPO'... The week after, I got multiple people that were on Lance ... Lance's camp, basically saying 'You better be quiet,' and I was quiet for three years. I have a business ... I have bikes that are sold ... and I was told that my sales might not be doing too well if ... just the publicity, the negative publicity."[http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/news/story?id=1841300 LeMond questions Armstrong's associations]. ESPN (July 19, 2004). Retrieved on August 21, 2011.
The same month, LeMond also stated to French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'': "Lance is ready to do anything to keep his secret. I don't know how he can continue to convince everybody of his innocence."[http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/news/story?id=1840215 Reporter denies Lance's allegations]. ESPN (July 17, 2004). Retrieved on August 21, 2011. Trek again threatened LeMond with allegedly breaching the "Moral Turpitude" section of their business agreement for making these comments, according to LeMond's 2008 complaint. In a 2007 interview, LeMond accused Armstrong of trying to sabotage his relationship with Trek bicycles, and described him by saying "I just think he's not a good person and that's all I can say. I mean, he's a facade, if you knew the real Lance Armstrong that I know. I think he fronts himself as a guy who is loving and caring. From my experience, he's not a nice guy and I've had some very difficult periods with him. And I don't believe he'll finish up having any friends in cycling."Interview in ''Rouleur,'' Guy Andrews, issue five, p. 26 In response Armstrong pointed the finger back at LeMond and suggested an iron injection LeMond received during the 1989 Giro d'Italia{{cite news| url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20040717&slug=toursnapshot17 | work=The Seattle Times | first=Mark | last=Akins | title=The soigneur is every cyclist's best friend | date=July 17, 2004}} was in reality an injection of EPO or some other performance-enhancing agent. “We will have the opportunity to tell the truth to the authorities, and Greg LeMond will tell the truth about 1989 I hope, because he, too, needs to tell the truth. I have nothing to hide.” {{cite web|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2010/07/news/greg-lemond-says-proble-could-end-lance-armstrong_129823#comment-63085250|title=Greg LeMond Says Probe Could End Lance Armstrong|work=Agence France Presse|date=July 18, 2010}} In March 2008, [[LeMond Racing Cycles|LeMond Cycling Inc]] sued Trek for failing to properly promote and distribute the LeMond brand, and for attempting to "silence" LeMond's public comments about doping, attributing this to the influence of Armstrong on Trek. Trek responded in April 2008 by severing business ties with LeMond.[http://www.trekbikes.com/pdf/media/en/Trek_PressRelease_FINAL.pdf TREK TO IMMEDIATELY SEVER RELATIONSHIP WITH GREG LEMOND] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609190914/http://www.trekbikes.com/pdf/media/en/Trek_PressRelease_FINAL.pdf |date=2012-06-09 }}, Media Release, trekbikes.com, 2008 4 8, retr 2012 10 13. At a press conference Armstrong gave September 2008 to announce his return to cycling, LeMond was on hand sitting in the front row, and publicly challenged Armstrong with questions about doping. Armstrong appeared angry and interrupted LeMond, telling him it was time to move on.{{cite news|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-09-25/sports/17906863_1_doping-greg-lemond-cycling|last=Vinton|first=Nathaniel|title=Greg LeMond and Lance Armstrong clash at news conference|work=New York Daily News|date= September 25, 2008|accessdate=October 14, 2012}} On February 16, 2011, Armstrong announced his retirement from competitive cycling. At the time he was facing a US federal investigation into [[Lance Armstrong doping allegations|doping allegations]]. In June 2012, USADA charged Armstrong with having used illicit performance-enhancing drugs.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/18655970|title=Lance Armstrong |accessdate=2012-06-30}} On August 24, 2012, the USADA announced that Armstrong had been issued a lifetime ban from competition, applicable to all sports which follow the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] code. The USADA report concluded that Armstrong engaged in "the most sophisticated, professionalized and successful doping program that sport has ever seen."{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/19903716 |title=Lance Armstrong: USADA report labels him 'a serial cheat' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2012-10-11 |accessdate=2012-11-10}} In addition, the USADA stripped Armstrong of his seven Tour de France titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.usada.org/media/sanction-armstrong8242012 |title=Lance Armstrong Receives Lifetime Ban And Disqualification Of Competitive Results For Doping Violations Stemming From His Involvement In The United States Postal Service Pro-Cycling Team Doping Conspiracy, USADA |publisher=Usada.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10}} On October 22, 2012, the [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI), the sport's governing body, announced its decision to accept USADA's findings.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cycling/20008520|title=Lance Armstrong: Governing body strips American of Tour wins|date=October 22, 2012|work=BBC News|accessdate=2012-10-22}} Armstrong chose not to appeal the decision to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/13587/Armstrongs-CAS-inaction-means-he-loses-chance-of-appeal-against-doping-sanctions.aspx|title=Armstrong’s CAS inaction means he loses chance of appeal against doping sanctions|publisher=Velonation.com|author=Shane Stokes|date=2012-12-29|accessdate=2013-01-02}} Despite having denied drug use throughout his career, in January 2013 he admitted to doping in a television interview conducted by [[Oprah Winfrey]].{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/sports/endurance/story/_/id/8855686/lance-armstrong-admits-doping-interview-oprah-winfrey|title=Lance Armstrong comes clean|date=January 17, 2013|publisher=ESPN.com News Services|accessdate=2013-01-18}}{{cite news|title=In Reversal, Armstrong Is Said to Weigh Admitting Drug Use|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/05/sports/cycling/lance-armstrong-said-to-weigh-admission-of-doping.html?emc=na&_r=0|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2013-01-05|first=Juliet|last=Macur|date=January 4, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Atty. denies report Lance Armstrong will admit doping|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-400_162-57562227/atty-denies-report-lance-armstrong-will-admit-doping/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=2013-01-05}} ==Floyd Landis== [[File:Floyd Landis stage 18 Tdf 2006.jpg|thumb|right|Floyd Landis at the start of Stage 18 of the 2006 Tour de France.]] On May 17, 2007, LeMond testified at a [[USADA]] hearing convened to weigh the evidence of doping by [[Floyd Landis]] during the [[2006 Tour de France]]. Under oath, LeMond described a phone conversation he had with Landis on August 6, 2006, as well as another with Landis' business manager, Will Geoghegan, on May 16, 2007, the evening before LeMond appeared to testify. The major points of the testimony were: *In an August 6 phone conversation, LeMond said he told Landis that "If you did (admit to having used banned substances), you could single-handedly change the sport. You could be the one who will salvage the sport." LeMond said Landis responded by saying "What good would it do? If I did, it would destroy a lot of my friends and hurt a lot of people." * In their conversation, LeMond had disclosed his history of childhood [[Child sexual abuse|sexual abuse]] to Landis, and said the secret had nearly destroyed him. LeMond stated he warned Landis. "(Lying about doping) will come back to haunt you when you are 40 or 50. If you have a moral compass and ethics, this will destroy you." * Will Geoghegan attempted to stop LeMond's testimony by calling LeMond at his personal mobile phone number. LeMond reported that Geoghegan claimed he was "his uncle" and that he would be at the hearing to talk about what had happened between them.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more-sports/landis-aide-threatens-lemond-article-1.252562|last=Quin |first=T.J. |work=New York Daily News | title=Landis aide threatens LeMond| date=2007-05-18}} LeMond's [[BlackBerry]], with Geoghegan's phone number captured in the call log, was entered into evidence. During a break in the testimony Geoghegan was observed by reporters approaching LeMond. LeMond later stated to reporters that Geoghegan had admitted making the call, and "tried to apologize".[http://www.bendweekly.com/news/6092.html Greg LeMond's steals focus in hearing on Floyd Landis]. Bendweekly.com. Retrieved on August 21, 2011. Following the testimony, Landis' legal team announced that Geoghegan had been fired. Landis admitted to being in the same room as Geoghegan when the call was made,[http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/cycling/columns/story?columnist=desimone_bonnie&id=2876323 Courtroom twists muffle Landis' doping denials]. ESPN (May 20, 2007). Retrieved on August 21, 2011. and defended his decision not to fire Geoghegan until after the LeMond testimony, saying he had been waiting for legal advice.[http://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/la-sp-landis23may23,1,6080136.story?coll=la-headlines-sports-olympics Landis asked about wardrobe] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Landis testified at the hearing that Geoghegan came to know of LeMond's childhood sexual abuse through discussions with the defense team, and obtained his personal mobile phone number by syncing their phones together. Geoghegan blamed "a beer or two" for his action, and entered an undisclosed rehab facility on May 21.[http://origin.mercurynews.com/sports/ci_5956994 Killion: Landis sees peril in going public] The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Office opened an investigation of the incident as a potential witness tampering[http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/05/23/news/californian/4_04_355_22_07.txt Landis' testimony centers on fired manager]. Nctimes.com (May 23, 2007). Retrieved on August 21, 2011. and then terminated the case without prosecution on July 31.Zeigler, Mark. (July 31, 2007) [http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/20070731-9999-1s31tour.html Landis spins wheels in court test]. Signonsandiego.com. Retrieved on August 21, 2011. LeMond's testimony was supported by an online posting Landis made on the Daily Peloton forum in which Landis stated that LeMond had disclosed personal information of a sensitive nature to Landis, and Landis threatened to use that information to damage LeMond if LeMond continued to speak out about Landis' doping case. ===Aftermath of the Landis testimony=== Several weeks after his testimony, Greg LeMond and his wife Kathy gave an extensive interview to the ''[[Sunday Times]]''. He provided additional details on the circumstances of his 2001 apology to Armstrong, stating that [[Trek Bicycle Corporation|Trek]], the longtime manufacturer and distributor of LeMond Racing Cycles, had threatened to end the relationship at the behest of Armstrong. He described the two years that followed the forced apology as the worst in his life, marked by self-destructive behavior that ultimately led him to disclose his sexual abuse to his wife and seek help. LeMond also described how being a victim of molestation had impacted both his racing career and his life since.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/cycling/article2010066.ece Cycle of Abuse] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605063556/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/cycling/article2010066.ece |date=June 5, 2010 }} In September 2007, Greg LeMond became a founding board member of the non-profit organization [[1in6|1in6.org]], whose mission is "to help men who have had unwanted or abusive sexual experiences in childhood live healthy, happy lives".[http://www.1in6.org 1in6.org] In 2010, after Floyd Landis admitted to doping while riding for Armstrong's USPS team and later at Phonak, he personally contacted LeMond to apologize for the events of 2007, and the two reconciled their differences.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703691804575255410855321120 "Cyclist Armstrong Denies Doping"] Reed Albergotti, ''Wall Street Journal,'' May 20, 2010{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/cycling/news/story?id=5211166|last=Ford |first=Bonnie D.|title=Landis makes amends with LeMond|work=ESPN.com |date=May 23, 2010}} Although he declined to make details of the conversation public, LeMond acknowledged his support of Landis and sought to assist his former adversary in obtaining legal representation for the ensuing US federal investigation. LeMond told the NY Daily News he believed 'most of Floyd Landis' statements' about doping.[http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more_sports/2010/05/20/2010-05-20_greg_lemond_believes_most_of_floyd_landis_statements_about_doping_in_cycling.html "Greg LeMond believes 'most of Floyd Landis' statements' about doping"] Nathaniel Vinton, ''New York Daily News,'' May 20, 2010 Troy Landis empathized to CyclingNews in 2015 that LeMond has personal distaste for Armstrong however has preference of some other riders: “For example just last year (2014) he was seen waving to crowds from a VIP car at the Tour along with Indurain and Hinault. Greg himself claims to have quit racing in the early 90s because EPO showed up and that is exactly when Indurain began winning. If clean riders were a victim of doping in the Armstrong era and he was a victim of doping in the early 90s then it defies reason why those two should be treated so differently,” [http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/landis-lemonds-anti-doping-stance-on-lance-armstrong-lacks-consistency/ "Landis Lemond's Antidoping Stance on Lance Armstrong Lacks Consistency"] ==Alberto Contador== [[File:Alberto Contador Paris-Nice 2007.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Alberto Contador]] On July 23, 2009, LeMond wrote an [[opinion article]][http://www.lemonde.fr/archives/article/2009/07/23/alberto-prouve-moi-qu-on-peut-croire-en-toi-par-greg-lemond_1221871_0.html Alberto, prove to me that we can believe in you]. Lemonde.fr (July 23, 2009). Retrieved on August 21, 2011. in the French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' where he questioned the validity of [[Alberto Contador]]'s climb up [[Verbier]] in the [[2009 Tour de France]]. In the piece, LeMond calculated that Contador's [[VO2 max]] was beyond what could be obtained without performance-enhancing products. The article stirred a fair amount of controversy as it put to question the Tour's best rider. A normal man might have a VO2 max between 38 and 43 ml/kg/min. LeMond had calculated Contador's VO2 max up the Verbier at 99.5 ml/kg/min. This is an astonishingly high number. Excellent endurance athletes when highly trained may reach into the 80s. Lance Armstrong had a VO2 max calculated at 85 ml/kg/min. Miguel Indurain had achieved a VO2 max of 88 ml/kg/min. Though LeMond's own VO2 max had at one time been calculated at an astounding 92.5 ml/kg/min, this was extremely unusual without performance-enhancing products, and was still significantly below that which LeMond calculated for Contador.Moore p. 58[http://texastailwind.wordpress.com/2009/02/13/vo2-to-the-max-performing-a-cycling-vo2-max-test/ Texastailwind VO2 max testing] Said LeMond: "The burden is then on Alberto Contador to prove he is physically capable of performing this feat without the use of performance-enhancing products." Other experts in exercise physiology questioned LeMond's calculation of 99.5 ml/kg/min. In an article appearing in Cyclingnews.com that same day as LeMond's piece, expert Andrew Coggan questioned LeMond's conclusions.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/contadors-climbing-credibility-questioned |last=Weislo|first=Laura|title=Contador's climbing credibility questioned|date=July 23, 2009|work=Cycling News}} Said Coggan: "a more reasonable estimate of Contador's power during that ascent is about 450 W, which would require a sustained VO2 of 'only' 80 mL/kg/min", which is "still high, but not so high that you can definitively state that it can only be achieved via doping." Using Coggan's numbers, if Contador had been operating at 90% up the climb of the Verbier, his VO2 Max would still be remarkably high at 89 mL/kg/min.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} Contador did not test positive for doping at the [[2009 Tour de France|2009 Tour]]. However, the following year he tested positive for [[clenbuterol]] after winning the [[2010 Tour de France|2010 Tour]]. On February 6, 2012, the Court of Arbitration for Sport stripped Contador of his results from July 2010 to February 2012, including his 2010 Tour and [[Giro d'Italia|2011 Giro]] titles.{{cite web |url=http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/5649/5048/0/Media20Release20_English_2012.02.06.pdf |title=Alberto Contador found guilty of an anti-doping rule violation by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS): suspension of two years |date=6 February 2012 |publisher=The Court of Arbitration for Sport |accessdate=13 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226222721/http://www.tas-cas.org/d2wfiles/document/5649/5048/0/Media20Release20_English_2012.02.06.pdf |archivedate=26 February 2012 |df= }} == References == ;Notes {{reflist|group=N}} ;Citations {{Reflist|2}} ;Bibliography * Moore, Richard (2012) "Slaying the Badger: Greg LeMond, Bernard Hinault and the Greatest Tour de France" Vintage Publishing, London, UK {{ISBN|1934030872}} [[Category:Doping in sport]] [[Category:Cycle racing]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Khalid Jassem
خالد جاسم | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1977|7|16}} | birth_place = [[Doha]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Qatar]]i | other_names = | residence = [[Qatar]] | occupation = TV Host & writer | years_active =1993–present | alma_mater = | known_for = [[Al Kass Sports Channels]] | notable_works = }} '''Khalid Jassem''' (Arabic: '''خالد جاسم''') (born 16 July 1977) is a [[Qatar]]i [[television]] presenter, [[television]] host, [[interview]]er, and writer on [[Al Kass Sports Channels]] since 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/23/209781.html|website=alarabiya.net|title=خالد جاسم: لست صاحب فكرة "المجلس".. و"بتّال" الأفضل|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=https://al-marsd.com/136131.html|website=al-marsd.com|title="المريسل" يدعو لمقاطعة الإعلامي القطري "خالد جاسم" بسبب تغريدة ساخرة • صحيفة المرصد|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=https://www.al-sharq.com/article/02/12/2017/%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D8%A8%D8%B1%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%AC-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AC%D9%84%D8%B3-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1-%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%84-2022-%D9%84%D9%83%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8|title=خالد جاسم راعي برنامج المجلس: قطر قالت مونديال 2022 لكل العرب - جريدة الشرق|website=al-sharq.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=https://sabq.org/5YGscQ|website=sabq.org|title=الدولي "حمود سلطان" يُكذّب القطري "خالد جاسم": الأمور طيبة وهذه ب|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://3alyoum.com/article/788667|author=الدمام - ناصر بن حسين|title=القطري خالد جاسم يكذب... الكابتن حمود سلطان: أنا بخير وحملة الإشاعات عادية - عين اليوم|website=3alyoum.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://alarab.qa/story/1289936/%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1-%D9%88%D8%A3%D9%87%D9%84%D9%87%D8%A7-%D8%AE%D8%B7-%D8%A3%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%B1|website=alarab.qa|title=العرب القطرية: خالد جاسم: قطر وأهلها «خط أحمر»|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.albiladpress.com/newspaper/3225/442727.html|title=جريدة البلاد | خالد جاسم: الدوري ملتقى حقيقي لأبناء وشباب المملكة|website=albiladpress.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=https://magazine.mondialar.com/2017/06/09/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B9%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D9%84%D9%85%D9%88%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%84-%D8%B1%D9%81/|title=الاعلامي القطري خالد جاسم لمونديال : رفع الحظر مكسب للانسان العراقي قبل الرياضي ونحن نفتخر بكم - مجلة مونديال|website=magazine.mondialar.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dc4mf.org/ar/content/8840|title=خالد جاسم لمركز الدوحة" للإعلام دور أساسي في انتشار التعصب الرياضي أو الحد منه" | DOHA CENTRE FOR MEDIA FREEDOM|website=dc4mf.org|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.al-jazirah.com/2007/20071130/sp46.htm|website=al-jazirah.com|title=2007/20071130/sp46|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.al-watan.com/news-details/id/89226|website=al-watan.com|title=خالد جاسم: مهما فعلنا لن نوفي قطر وقائدها حقهما|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alkass.net/alkass/faces.aspx|author=قنوات الكأس الرياضية|website=alkass.net|title=قنوات الكأس الرياضية|accessdate=2017-12-30}} ==Bio== '''Jassem''' born in [[Doha]]. He joined [[Qatar Television]] at the end of 1993 and moved to [[Al Jazeera]] in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://almnatiq.net/446843/|title=الإعلامي القطري خالد جاسم يخفي الحقائق إجحافاً ويظهر الجحود ظلماً | صحيفة المناطق الإلكترونية|website=almnatiq.net|accessdate=2017-12-30}} He has been a member of [[Al Jazeera]] and has served as Editor,{{cite web|url=http://www.arriyadiyah.com/node/1003391/%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%84%D9%8A%D8%A9/%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%87%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%84-%D9%8A%D8%AD%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC-%D9%88%D8%B5%D9%81%D8%A9-%D8%B3%D8%AD%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D8%A5%D8%AB%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%B0%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%87-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%87%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%8B-%D8%A8%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%AC|title=خالد جاسم: الهلال يحتاج وصفة سحرية .. على سامي إثبات ذاته .. الأهلي خاسراً بخروج أسامة | الرياضية|website=arriyadiyah.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}} Archivist, Correspondent and Head of Correspondents for the [[Sport]]s Department worldwide. Until 2003, and then signed another contract for [[Al Jazeera]] Sports Channel, and in 2005 came out of AlJazeera [[Sports]] as a manager of the channel league and cup until May 2011, and then submitted his resignation from AlJazeera Sports.{{cite web|url=https://qbsnews.com/8353/|title=تغريدة ساخرة للإعلامي القطري خالد جاسم تثير الغضب ..والمريسل يدعو لمقاطعته - صحيفة قبس الإلكترونية|website=qbsnews.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://akhbar-alkhaleej.com/news/article/1084935|title=أخبار الخليج | خالد جاسم: دوري خالد بن حمد ملتقى حقيقي لأبناء وشباب المملكة|website=akhbar-alkhaleej.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alyaum.com/article/2756480|author=صحيفة اليوم|website=alyaum.com|title=صحيفة اليوم : نجاح شقيقي خالد في المجلس اغضب الحاقدين فحاربوه|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.raya.com/news/pages/09d2d217-9b1a-4262-aa8f-3b9273f4e9bf|title=جريدة الراية -خالد جاسم: الحصار كشف|website=raya.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/852442|title=جريدة الرياض | خالد جاسم: لا أستطيع مقاومة الثريد والهريس.. والتخفيضات هوايتي|website=alriyadh.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.okaz.com.sa/article/893051|author=حاوره: نادر العنزي|title=خالد جاسم: طعم دوريكم "جميل" ومذاق النصر "حراق" - أخبار السعودية | صحيفة عكاظ|website=okaz.com.sa|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sportksa.net/main/archives/306845|title=عزت يستقبل وفد قنوات “الكأس” برئاسة الاعلامي خالد جاسم - صحيفة سبورت السعودية|website=sportksa.net|accessdate=2017-12-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alkebar.com/news.php?action=show&id=17094|title=خالد جاسم: متجر النصر عالمي .. ومتجر الهلال صغير - الكبار - أول صحيفة رياضية الكترونية سعودية خاصة بالأندية الكبار|website=alkebar.com|accessdate=2017-12-30}} ==See also== * [[List of television presenters]] * [[Jamal Rayyan]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.mbc.net/ar/programs/action-ya-dawry/articles/%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D8%B6%D9%8A%D9%81-%D8%A3%D9%83%D8%B4%D9%86-%D9%8A%D8%A7-%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A.html An Interview with Khalid Jassim ('''خالد جاسم''') on MBC] * [http://brkaq8.com/114366.html Khalid Jassem ('''خالد جاسم''') During the presentation of the almajles program] * [http://www.almadaen.com.sa/252247/%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF-%D8%AA%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%82%D8%B6%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B9%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85/ Khalid Jassem ('''خالد جاسم''') with almadaen paper] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jassem, Khalid}} [[Category:Qatari television presenters]] [[Category:Al Jazeera people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Qatari writers]] [[Category:Qatari journalists]] [[Category:Sports journalists]] [[Category:1977 births]]

{{Infobox tennis tournament | name = Monterrey WCT | type = defunct | founded = 1976 | ended = 1983 | event name = Monterrey WCT | tour = [[World Championship Tennis|WCT Tour]] (1976–77, 1981-83) | surface = [[Tennis court#Carpet courts|Carpet]] (1976–77, 1981-83) }} The '''Monterrey WCT''' was a men's [[tennis]] tournament played in [[Monterrey, Mexico]] from 1976 to 1977 and 1981 to 1983. The event was part of the [[World Championship Tennis|WCT Tour]] and was played on indoor carpet courts. ==Finals== ===Singles=== {|class=wikitable |- !style="width:40px"|Year !style="width:200px"|Champions !style="width:200px"|Runners-up !style="width:140px" class="unsortable"|Score |- | 1976{{Cite web|url=http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?event=1010004303&tournament=1010002859|title=Men's Singles - Main Draw|publisher=[[International Tennis Federation]]|accessdate=2010-10-07}} || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Eddie Dibbs]] || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Harold Solomon]] || 7–6, 6–2 |- | 1977{{Cite web|url=http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?event=1010004304&tournament=1010002860|title=Men's Singles - Main Draw|publisher=[[International Tennis Federation]]|accessdate=2010-10-07}} || {{flagicon|POL}} [[Wojtek Fibak]] || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Vitas Gerulaitis]] || 6–4, 6–3 |- | 1981 || {{flagicon|RSA|1928}} [[Johan Kriek]] || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Vitas Gerulaitis]] || 7–6, 3–6, 7–6 |- | 1982 || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jimmy Connors]] || {{flagicon|RSA|1928}} [[Johan Kriek]] || 6–2, 3–6, 6–3 |- | 1983 || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sammy Giammalva]] || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Ben Testerman]] || 6–4, 3–6, 6–3 |} ===Doubles=== {|class=wikitable |- !style="width:40px"|Year !style="width:200px"|Champions !style="width:200px"|Runners-up !style="width:140px" class="unsortable"|Score |- | 1976{{Cite web|url=http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?event=1010015698&tournament=1010002859|title=Men's Doubles - Main Draw|publisher=[[International Tennis Federation]]|accessdate=2010-10-07}} || {{flagicon|USA}} [[Brian Gottfried]]
{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Raúl Ramírez]] || {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Ross Case]]
{{flagicon|AUS}} [[Geoff Masters]] || 6–2, 4–6, 6–3 |- | 1977{{Cite web|url=http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?event=1010015699&tournament=1010002860|title=Men's Doubles - Main Draw|publisher=[[International Tennis Federation]]|accessdate=2010-10-07}} || {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Ross Case]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Bill Scanlon]] || 3–6, 6–3, 6–4 |- | 1981 || {{flagicon|RSA|1928}} [[Kevin Curren]]

{{flagicon|AUS}} [[Russell Simpson (tennis)|Russell Simpson]] || 7–6, 6–3 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Monterrey WCT tournament}} [[Category:World Championship Tennis]] [[Category:Tennis tournaments in Mexico]] [[Category:Defunct tennis tournaments]] [[Category:Defunct sports competitions in Mexico]] [[Category:1976 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:1983 disestablishments in Mexico]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1976]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events disestablished in 1983]] [[Category:Sport in Monterrey]] {{Mexico-sport-stub}}
